Patients typically present with a predisposition to developing blood-related cancers (lymphoma, leukemia) rather than solid tumors on the skin.

 

Option C. Cockayne’s syndrome: Cockayne syndrome is associated with photosensitivity and growth problems in children, but it is not associated with the development of malignancies, including skin tumors.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is primarily associated with an increased risk of colon cancer and other internal malignancies, but it is not associated with skin tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in nucleotide excision repair, leading to a high risk of developing multiple skin tumors due to the inability to repair DNA damage caused by UV light exposure.

questions.text: Paris green powder is used for killing of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anopheles larva

 

Paris green powder is a chemical compound known as copper acetoarsenate, which is used as an anti-larval agent in the control of mosquito populations, under National Vector Borne Disease Control Program, India.

 

The mechanism of action of Paris green is that it acts as a stomach poison when ingested by the larvae. This disrupts the normal biological functions of the larvae, effectively killing them before they can mature into adult mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria parasite: Paris green powder does not target the malaria parasite directly. Instead, it targets the mosquito larvae, which are vectors for the parasite.

 

Option C. Mites: Paris green powder is not effective against mites; it is specifically used against mosquito larvae.

 

Option D. Adult mosquito: While there are chemical agents such as DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion that are used to target adult mosquitoes. These adulticides work as nerve or contact poisons, inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme in adult mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antilarval measures: Paris green – 2% dust applied in dose of 1 kg per hectare; ‘stomach poison’ to larvae but harmless to humans, animals or fish

 

Antiadult measures: DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures. On examination, blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

This case presents a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy, as indicated by the symptoms of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, along with severely elevated blood pressure (220/110 mmHg). In hypertensive emergencies, the goal is to rapidly reduce blood pressure using intravenous medications to prevent further organ damage.

 

IV Labetalol is a preferred treatment in hypertensive emergencies, especially those involving encephalopathy. Labetalol is a combined alpha and beta-blocker that can reduce blood pressure quickly and effectively, making it ideal for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Nifedipine: Oral nifedipine is not appropriate for hypertensive emergencies because it does not act rapidly enough, and oral medications are generally avoided in such acute settings.

 

Option B. Oral Nicardipine capsules: Like oral nifedipine, oral nicardipine is not suitable for emergencies due to its slower onset of action. Nicardipine is more effective in its intravenous form for such cases.

 

Option C. IV Nitroglycerine: Although IV nitroglycerine can be used in hypertensive emergencies, it is not the best choice for hypertensive encephalopathy. Nitroglycerine is more commonly used in cases involving acute coronary syndromes or pulmonary edema, but it is usually avoided in patients with CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for Hypertensive emergencies:

 

  • Encephalopathy - Nicardipine or IV Labetalol

  • Intracranial Hemorrhage - Nicardipine or Labetalol

  • Acute Coronary Syndrome – IV Nitroglycerin

  • Pulmonary Edema - Intravenous Nitroglycerin / Sodium Nitroprusside

  • Aortic Dissection – Nicardipine in combination with Esmolol or Labetalol

  • In Pregnancy - Labetalol

questions.text: Accidental death occurred in a man 3 days after the accident. During the postmortem examination, bleeding was observed in the head that was not washed away by water. This can be due to: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid bleeding

 

In postmortem examinations, different types of intracranial hemorrhages can be observed. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is characterized by bleeding that occurs between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater. This type of bleeding is protected by the arachnoid mater, making it resistant to being washed away by water during an autopsy. The presence of persistent bleeding after washing indicates that it is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Note – EDH Vs SDH Vs SAH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural bleeding: Epidural hemorrhage (EDH) occurs between the dura mater and the skull. It is typically easy to identify and does not remain after washing.

 

Option C. SDH: Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. This type of bleeding usually washes away with water during an autopsy.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal bleeding: Intraparenchymal bleeding occurs within the brain tissue itself. While it may not wash away completely, the described scenario specifically matches the characteristics of subarachnoid bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is identified by the persistence of bleeding in the head that is not washed away by water during an autopsy, due to its protection by the arachnoid mater

questions.text: A log dose-response curve (DRC) was plotted with isoprenaline alone (black line) and with isoprenaline in the presence of increasing doses of propranolol (red, green and purple lines), as shown below. The graph shows that propranolol is a: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Competitive antagonist

 

Propranolol is identified as a competitive antagonist based on the nature of the dose-response curve (DRC) observed in the graph. When isoprenaline is used alone, it produces a standard dose-response curve. However, when propranolol is introduced, it causes a parallel shift of the dose-response curve to the right. This rightward shift without a change in the maximal response is characteristic of a competitive antagonist. This indicates that propranolol competes with isoprenaline for the same binding site on the beta-1 receptors, thereby inhibiting the action of isoprenaline in a reversible manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial agonist: A partial agonist would produce a response but not to the full extent of a full agonist. Propranolol does not produce a response on its own, but instead blocks the response of isoprenaline, which is why it is not a partial agonist.

 

Option B. Agonist: An agonist would produce a biological response by activating the receptor. Propranolol, on the other hand, inhibits the action of an agonist like isoprenaline, hence it is not an agonist.

 

Option D. Non-competitive antagonist: A non-competitive antagonist would reduce the maximal response that the agonist can produce. The graph shows no reduction in the maximal response but rather a shift to the right, which is not consistent with non-competitive antagonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propranolol is a competitive antagonist of isoprenaline, causing a parallel rightward shift in the dose-response curve without affecting the maximal response.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal background, after 1 week is found dead with advanced decomposition. What would you do to recognize the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA profiling

 

After one week liquefaction occurs, so the body undergoes significant decomposition. General recognition is not helpful due to the gross distortion of the body. Dental records are also not useful because teeth typically fall out within three to five days post-mortem. Fingerprints can be compromised as the skin begins to degrade, with degloving of the skin occurring within three to five days and complete skin decomposition taking up to one month. However, DNA profiling remains a reliable method even in advanced decomposition, as DNA can be extracted from bones and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General recognition: This is ineffective after a week of decomposition due to the significant distortion and liquefaction of the body.

 

Option C. Dental records: Teeth fall out within three to five days after death, making dental records unreliable for identification after one week.

 

Option D. Finger prints: The skin undergoes degloving within three to five days and further decomposition, making fingerprinting unreliable. Additionally, without a criminal background, there would be no pre-existing fingerprint records for comparison.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: Post-translational modification common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subunit aggregation

 

Post-translational modifications occur after the synthesis of a protein and are crucial for the protein to attain its functional form. Subunit aggregation is a process that involves the assembly of multiple protein subunits to form a functional complex. This process is common to several proteins, including collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin:

 

  • Collagen forms a triple helix structure by aggregating three polypeptide chains.
  • Hemoglobin is composed of two alpha and two beta globin chains that come together to form a functional protein capable of oxygen transport.
  • Immunoglobulins are composed of heavy and light chains that must aggregate to form the functional antibody.

 

Thus, the common post-translational modification among these proteins is subunit aggregation, where individual protein subunits come together to create a functional unit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splicing: This is a post-transcriptional modification that occurs at the RNA level, not at the protein level. It involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA and is not related to post-translational modifications.

 

Option B. Gene editing: Gene editing involves altering the DNA sequence, which occurs before transcription and translation. It is not a post-translational modification and does not pertain to protein processing.

 

Option D. Hydroxylation: Hydroxylation is a post-translational modification that specifically applies to collagen. It involves the addition of hydroxyl groups to proline and lysine residues, a process that requires vitamin C. However, hydroxylation is not a common modification across collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulins, which makes it an incorrect answer in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subunit aggregation is a post-translational modification common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin, where multiple protein subunits assemble to form a functional protein complex.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic was presented with complaints of confusion, tingling sensation. His history revealed polished rice is his main diet. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beriberi

 

The patient described in the question is a chronic alcoholic and has a diet primarily consisting of polished rice. Both factors are significant because they contribute to a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Alcohol inhibits the absorption of thiamine in the intestines, and polished rice, which has had its aleurone layer removed during processing, is devoid of thiamine.

 

Thiamine deficiency can lead to Beriberi, which has two forms:

 

  • Dry Beriberi: Characterized by symmetrical motor and sensory neuropathy, often with symptoms such as confusion, tingling, tenderness, and muscle cramps. The symptoms mentioned in the question, such as confusion and tingling, align with this form.
  • Wet Beriberi: This form is associated with high-output cardiac failure and edema, which is not highlighted in this patient's symptoms but is also a consequence of severe thiamine deficiency.

 

Given the patient’s symptoms and history, the correct diagnosis is Beriberi due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phrynoderma: This is a condition associated with vitamin A deficiency, leading to follicular hyperkeratosis. It is not related to the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, resulting in scaling on the skin’s surface. It is unrelated to the neurological symptoms and dietary history presented in the question.

 

Option D. Eczema: Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is a condition that makes the skin red, inflamed, and itchy. It does not correlate with the patient’s symptoms of confusion and tingling, nor with thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcoholism and a diet primarily consisting of polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in Beriberi, which can manifest as either dry (neurological symptoms) or wet (cardiac symptoms) Beriberi.

questions.text: Epithelial lining of trachea is made of which type of cells? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells

 

The epithelial lining of the trachea consists of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to be layered (stratified) due to the varying positions of the nuclei within the cells, but in reality, all cells are attached to the basement membrane, making it a "pseudostratified" layer. The presence of cilia on the apical surface of the cells helps in the movement of mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, which is crucial for maintaining respiratory health.

 

 

 

Note - Kartagener Syndrome which is characterized by a triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and infertility. This syndrome is linked to defects in the ciliary structure and function, known as primary ciliary dyskinesia, affecting not just respiratory epithelium but also other ciliated cells in the body, such as those in the reproductive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciliated columnar cells: Although the cells are ciliated, they are not simply columnar; they are pseudostratified columnar cells.

 

Option B. Non-ciliated cuboidal cells: This type of epithelium is typically found in smaller ducts and glands, not in the respiratory tract, making it incorrect for the trachea.

 

Option D. Simple columnar cells: This type of epithelium is found in areas like the gastrointestinal tract, where absorption is a key function. It is not characteristic of the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trachea is lined with pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which plays a critical role in trapping and moving particles out of the respiratory system to keep the airways clear.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PET

 

The image provided shows a comparison between three types of imaging modalities: PET, CT, and PET-CT. PET (Positron Emission Tomography) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. In this case, the PET scan highlights areas of the body where the radioactive glucose analog 18F-FDG has been absorbed, typically areas with high glucose metabolism such as tumors.

 

The combined PET-CT image integrates the metabolic information from the PET scan with the anatomical detail provided by the CT scan, which allows for precise localization of the metabolic activity within the body's structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG: Ultrasound (USG) uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It does not produce the type of image shown in this question.

 

Option B. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures. The images from MRI are different from those of PET scans, which focus on metabolic activity.

 

Option D. X-ray: X-rays provide images based on the absorption of X-ray photons by different tissues, primarily used to visualize bone structures. The image shown is not an X-ray, as it does not display the typical bone-focused detail of X-ray imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation shown in the image is a PET scan (and PET-CT), which highlights areas of high metabolic activity, commonly used for detecting cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

 

Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) can be measured through various methods, including gas chromatography. For accurate measurement of BAC, the blood sample is typically collected in a gray-top vial. This vial contains a mixture of sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate.

 

Sodium fluoride acts as a preservative and prevents glycolysis, which could otherwise lower the concentration of alcohol in the blood sample.

 

However, when using the potassium dichromate test for BAC, potassium dichromate is included in the sample collection tube. In this test, potassium dichromate, which is orange in color, reacts with ethanol present in the blood sample. This reaction converts ethanol to acetic acid and simultaneously reduces potassium dichromate to chromium, which turns the solution green. The intensity of the green color directly correlates with the alcohol concentration in the sample, providing a visual indication of BAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin + EDTA: This combination is generally used as an anticoagulant in blood samples for various laboratory tests but is not specifically used for BAC measurement.

 

Option C. Heparin: While heparin is an anticoagulant, it is not used in the collection tubes for blood alcohol concentration testing.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate: Sodium citrate is also an anticoagulant, commonly used in coagulation studies, but it is not relevant for BAC measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures of anthropometry? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight-for-height

 

Wasting in a child is an indicator of acute malnutrition and is assessed using the weight-for-height measure. This metric evaluates whether a child’s weight is appropriate for their height, which reflects their current nutritional status. Wasting indicates that a child has lost weight rapidly in relation to their height, usually due to insufficient nutrient intake or disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight-for-age: This measure is used to assess whether a child is underweight, which is an acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option C. Height-for-age: This measure is used to assess stunting, which indicates chronic malnutrition. Stunting reflects a long-term deficiency in nutrition, resulting in reduced growth in height.

 

Option D. Height-for-weight: This option is not a standard anthropometric measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wasting in a child is assessed using the weight-for-height measure, indicating acute malnutrition

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with dyslipidemia has persistently elevated triglyceride levels (600 mg/dL) despite treatment with rosuvastatin. What will be the next step? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

 

In cases where a patient has dyslipidemia with persistently elevated triglyceride levels, particularly above 500 mg/dL, there is a significant risk of developing pancreatitis. The primary goal in such situations is to lower the triglyceride levels to mitigate this risk. Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil or fenofibrate, are the treatment of choice for reducing triglyceride levels effectively. They act by decreasing the hepatic secretion of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and increasing the clearance of triglycerides from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is used to reduce low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels. It works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. While it is effective for lowering LDL, it is not the first-line treatment for elevated triglycerides.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin, or vitamin B3, was previously used to lower both LDL and triglyceride levels. However, it is no longer commonly used in practice due to its side effects and lack of significant additional benefit over other treatments.

 

Option D. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that is primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol. It is not particularly effective in reducing triglyceride levels and can cause gastrointestinal side effects, making it a less favorable option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with triglyceride levels above 500 mg/dL, fibrates such as gemfibrozil are the preferred treatment to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old patient presented with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was performed, and the reports are as follows: (FMGE JULY 2024)

 

  • Opening pressure – elevated
  • Appearance – cloudy
  • Cell count – 80 (70% PMNs)
  • Sugar – 35 mg/dL
  • Protein – 200 mg/dL

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Bacterial Meningitis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of meningitis: fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis from the lumbar puncture provides several key clues:

 

  • Elevated opening pressure, which is common in bacterial meningitis.
  • Cloudy appearance of the CSF, indicating a high number of cells or increased protein.
  • Cell count of 80 with 70% polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs), which is highly indicative of bacterial infection as it typically shows a neutrophilic predominance.
  • Low glucose level (35 mg/dL) and elevated protein level (200 mg/dL), which are consistent with bacterial meningitis due to the consumption of glucose by bacteria and increased protein from the inflammatory process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Viral Meningitis: Viral meningitis usually presents with a lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, normal or slightly elevated protein, and normal glucose levels. This does not match the neutrophil predominance and low glucose levels seen in this case.

 

Option C. TB Meningitis: TB meningitis often shows a lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, significantly elevated protein levels, and moderately low glucose levels. While the glucose and protein levels could fit, the neutrophil predominance makes TB meningitis less likely.

 

Option D. Fungal Meningitis: Fungal meningitis typically presents with a mixed or lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, elevated protein, and low glucose. Neutrophilic predominance is not characteristic of fungal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute bacterial meningitis is characterized by elevated opening pressure, cloudy CSF, a high cell count with neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, and elevated protein levels in the CSF.

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radkowski

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects adolescent males. The staging system specifically related to JNA is the Radkowski staging system. This system helps to classify the extent of the tumor based on its location and spread:

 

  • Stage I: Tumor confined to the nasopharynx, nasal cavity, and may involve the paranasal sinuses.
  • Stage II: Tumor extends into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Stage III: Tumor invades the infratemporal fossa.
  • Stage IV: Tumor extends to the intracranial space, including the foramen magnum.

 

The Radkowski staging system helps in determining the surgical approach and prognosis for patients with JNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for various carcinomas, especially solid tumors like those in breast cancer, lung cancer, etc. It stands for Tumor, Node, Metastasis.

 

Option B. Ann Arbor: The Ann Arbor staging system is used for lymphomas, particularly Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

 

Option D. Dukes: The Dukes staging system is used for colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

questions.text: A young woman wants to take the post-coital pill. Which one should be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LNG

 

The post-coital pill, also known as emergency contraception, is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. The preferred choice for emergency contraception, particularly in many countries including India, is Levonorgestrel (LNG).

 

LNG (Levonorgestrel): Available under brand names such as the "easy pill," it contains 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse to effectively prevent pregnancy. It is a single-dose regimen that is well-tolerated and has fewer side effects compared to other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Norethisterone: This is not used for emergency contraception. It is primarily used in other hormonal treatments, such as for menstrual disorders.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Estrogen alone is not used for emergency contraception due to the risk of side effects and its lower efficacy compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option D. Estrogen + Progesterone (Yuzpe regimen): Although this method can be used for emergency contraception, it is not preferred due to the higher incidence of side effects like nausea and vomiting. This method involves taking a high dose of estrogen and progesterone and repeating it after 12 hours, which is less convenient and less well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred emergency contraceptive pill is Levonorgestrel (LNG), to be taken as a single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

The correct answer is Beta hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin). Beta hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta during pregnancy. In the context of an ectopic pregnancy, which is a pregnancy located outside the uterine cavity (commonly in the fallopian tubes), the measurement of Beta hCG levels is crucial for diagnosis and management.

 

Beta hCG: In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, Beta hCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours. In ectopic pregnancies, these levels usually rise more slowly. Additionally, Beta hCG levels are used to determine the mode of management for unruptured ectopic pregnancies (medical, surgical, or expectant management) and to assess the discriminatory zone, which is the level of Beta hCG at which an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estradiol: This is a form of estrogen, a hormone involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy, but it is not a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Progesterone: This hormone supports the early stages of pregnancy by preparing the uterine lining for implantation, but it is not specifically used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Estriol: Another form of estrogen produced during pregnancy, it is not used as a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.

questions.text: Which of the following eye sign is given in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tache noire

 

The image depicts a condition known as Tache noire, characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera. This occurs due to the deposition of bacteria and dust, usually within 3 to 4 hours after death. Tache noire is a postmortem change observed in the eyes of the deceased when the eyelids are partially open, leading to drying of the exposed sclera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kevorkian sign: This sign involves the fragmentation of blood in blood vessels into columns due to the loss of blood pressure after death. The characteristic appearance is shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. Corneal changes: These involve alterations in the cornea, such as clouding, that occur after death. However, the given image does not show corneal clouding but rather a specific discoloration indicative of Tache noire.

 

Option D. Vitreous humour changes: These refer to alterations in the vitreous humour of the eye postmortem, such as changes in its consistency or color. The image does not depict such changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tache noire is a postmortem change characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera due to drying and deposition of bacteria and dust, typically occurring within a few hours after death.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. One of the well-known side effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increased risk of fungal infections, particularly candidal infections of the genital tract. This is because SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, creating an environment conducive to fungal growth. Therefore, in patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, such as the 60-year-old female in this case, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: The most common side effect of metformin is gastrointestinal upset, particularly diarrhea. It does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: This sulfonylurea drug primarily causes hypoglycemia as a side effect. It does not have a significant association with increased risk of fungal infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: This drug can cause weight gain due to fluid retention but does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine poisoning

 

Gastric lavage, also known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, involves the removal of the stomach's contents via a tube. It is contraindicated in certain situations due to the risks involved.

 

Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine is a convulsive poison. Performing gastric lavage on a patient with strychnine poisoning is highly dangerous because it can induce further convulsions and seizures. Gastric lavage acts as a stimulus, which can exacerbate the convulsions, leading to a higher risk of complications including aspiration of stomach contents into the lungs.

 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

 

  • Corrosive substances (an absolute C/I): Risk of gastric perforation except for carbolic acid, which hardens the stomach wall.
  • Convulsive patients: Risk of aspiration.
  • Comatose patients: Also at risk of aspiration unless the airway is protected.
  • Kerosene & other volatile poison, including hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons are volatile and can cause chemical pneumonitis if aspirated.
  • Oesophageal Varices

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ingestion of paraldehyde: Paraldehyde ingestion does not have the same risk of inducing convulsions or seizures. Gastric lavage can be considered in some cases, but it is not absolutely contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ingestion of hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons, such as kerosene, are volatile and pose a high risk of aspiration leading to chemical pneumonitis. While this is also a contraindication, the most critical contraindication here is strychnine poisoning due to the additional risk of inducing seizures.

 

Option D. Iron tablet ingestion: Iron tablets do not pose a high risk of convulsions or severe aspiration. Gastric lavage can be used in cases of iron tablet ingestion if done early and under proper medical supervision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in cases of strychnine poisoning due to the high risk of inducing further convulsions and seizures, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

questions.text: Innervation of lateral rectus is by which nerve? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CN VI

 

The lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (abduction), is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This nerve specifically controls the lateral rectus muscle, allowing for the lateral movement of the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CN III (Oculomotor nerve): The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the other extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It is not responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option B. CN IV (Trochlear nerve): The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which is involved in downward and outward movement of the eye. It does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option D. CN VII (Facial nerve): The facial nerve is primarily responsible for the muscles of facial expression. It does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve (CN VI), also known as the abducens nerve.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and skinny appearance. Which of the following condition best fit the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marasmus

 

Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by energy deficiency. A child with marasmus typically has a very thin, wasted appearance due to the loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous fat. This condition results from inadequate intake of calories and protein over a prolonged period. In the context of the question, the 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and a skinny appearance aligns with the clinical presentation of marasmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor: (Fatty baby/ anasarca) This condition is also a form of severe malnutrition but is primarily due to protein deficiency rather than a total calorie deficiency. Children with kwashiorkor often appear with edema, an enlarged liver, and a swollen abdomen. They may have a more plump appearance due to fluid retention, not a skinny one.

 

Option C. Stunting: This term refers to chronic malnutrition that results in reduced growth rate and height for a child's age. While stunted growth is a sign of malnutrition, it does not specifically account for the muscle wasting and extreme thinness described in the question.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as marasmus directly fits the description provided in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat, leading to a very thin, emaciated appearance in affected children.

questions.text: A person had a fall on an outstretched hand. He presented with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scaphoid

 

The scaphoid bone is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist and forms the floor of the anatomical snuffbox, which is an important surface landmark on the dorsum of the hand. When a person falls on an outstretched hand, the force is transmitted through the thumb to the wrist, often resulting in a fracture of the scaphoid bone. This type of injury is common and is characterized by pain and tenderness at the base of the thumb, specifically in the anatomical snuffbox region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone located more centrally in the wrist. Although it can be injured in falls, it is more commonly associated with dislocations rather than fractures when compared to the scaphoid, and it does not typically present with pain specifically at the base of the thumb.

 

Option B. Pisiform: The pisiform is a small, pea-shaped carpal bone situated on the anterior (palmar) side of the wrist. It is not commonly involved in injuries related to falls on an outstretched hand, especially when pain and swelling are localized to the base of the thumb.

 

Option D. Trapezium: The trapezium is a carpal bone located just distal to the scaphoid and is involved in articulating with the first metacarpal bone of the thumb. However, it is less likely to be the primary bone injured in a fall on an outstretched hand, as the scaphoid is more susceptible to fractures in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scaphoid bone is the most common carpal bone injured in falls on an outstretched hand, especially when the patient presents with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was on metronidazole therapy for a bacterial infection. He attended a party and consumed alcohol. Shortly after, he developed symptoms including intense facial flushing, severe nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. What is the likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug interaction

 

The patient’s symptoms are indicative of a disulfiram-like reaction, which occurs when alcohol is consumed while taking certain medications, including metronidazole. Metronidazole inhibits the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This results in symptoms such as facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole overdose: Metronidazole overdose would typically present with neurological symptoms such as seizures, neuropathy, and encephalopathy, rather than the acute symptoms seen here, which are triggered by alcohol consumption.

 

Option B. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning presents with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbances, and in severe cases, metabolic acidosis. The context of alcohol consumption and the specific symptoms make methanol poisoning unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, agitation, anxiety, hallucinations, and seizures. It does not present with the acute flushing and gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this case, which are more consistent with a disulfiram-like reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram-like reaction by "CGMP" (mnemonic)

 

C – Cefoperazone

 

G – Griseofulvin

 

M – Metronidazole

 

P – Procarbazine

 

Additionally, sometimes can be caused by Isoniazid and chlorpropamide.

 

This reaction typically includes symptoms such as flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations when alcohol is consumed.

questions.text: Which channel opens when action potential begins? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Na+ influx

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron begins with the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels. When a neuron receives a sufficient threshold stimulus, these sodium channels open, allowing Na+ ions to flow into the cell. This influx of positive sodium ions causes the membrane potential to become more positive, a process known as depolarization.

 

Depolarization is the first phase of the action potential, which is essential for the propagation of electrical signals along the neuron. Following depolarization, the action potential continues with other ion movements that facilitate the signal's transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cl- influx: Chloride ions typically move into the cell during inhibitory postsynaptic potentials, causing hyperpolarization (making the inside of the cell more negative). This is not related to the initiation of action potentials.

 

Option C. K+ efflux: Potassium efflux occurs during the repolarization phase of the action potential, not at the beginning. Repolarization helps restore the resting membrane potential after depolarization.

 

Option D. Ca2+ influx: Calcium influx is crucial in various cellular processes, such as neurotransmitter release at synapses. However, it is not involved in the initial depolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron is marked by the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels, leading to Na+ influx and membrane depolarization.

questions.text: A gymnasium owner found that people drank ice tea while exercising in his gym. He further mentioned that the subsequent weight loss was solely due to ice tea. This is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spurious association

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship between two variables is falsely inferred, often due to the presence of a confounding variable. In this case, the gym owner observed that people drank ice tea while exercising and then experienced weight loss. However, the weight loss is actually due to the exercise, not the ice tea.

 

The gym owner incorrectly attributed the weight loss solely to the consumption of ice tea, which is a classic example of a spurious association—where the real cause (exercise) is overlooked or ignored, and an unrelated factor (ice tea) is wrongly identified as the cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct association: This would imply a straightforward cause-and-effect relationship; such as exercise leading directly to weight loss. This is not applicable here because the claim was that ice tea, not exercise, caused the weight loss.

 

Option B. Indirect association: An indirect association occurs when the relationship between two variables is mediated by one or more additional variables. For example, exercise might lead to increased metabolism, which in turn leads to weight loss. This is not applicable in this scenario because the weight loss is directly due to exercise, not mediated by another factor like ice tea.

 

Option D. No association: This would imply that there is no relationship at all between the variables. However, in this scenario, the gym owner has incorrectly claimed an association, which makes it a spurious association rather than no association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship is wrongly inferred between two variables due to a confounding factor. In this case, the gym owner incorrectly attributed weight loss to ice tea consumption rather than the true cause, which is exercise.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for patent ductus arteriosus, which structure in close relation to it can be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth, leaving an open connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. Surgical correction of this defect involves closing the ductus arteriosus.

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops under the arch of the aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum (the remnant of the ductus arteriosus). Due to its close proximity to the ductus arteriosus, this nerve is at risk of being damaged during surgical procedures aimed at correcting PDA. Injury to this nerve can result in hoarseness, voice changes, or even vocal cord paralysis due to its role in innervating the muscles of the larynx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagus nerve: While the vagus nerve is in the vicinity, it does not have the same close relationship with the ductus arteriosus as the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The vagus nerve primarily runs along the side of the neck and thorax without looping directly near the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. Right recurrent laryngeal nerve: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the right subclavian artery and does not pass near the ductus arteriosus, making it less likely to be damaged during surgery on the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, runs more anteriorly in the thorax and does not have a close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus, thus it is not at significant risk during PDA surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at significant risk of injury during surgical procedures for patent ductus arteriosus due to its close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia, and feelings of hopelessness. The patient has a history of a similar episode with full recovery approximately five years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent Depressive Disorder

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder (RDD) is diagnosed when a patient has experienced two or more depressive episodes, with each episode separated by at least two months of remission. In this case, the patient presents with symptoms of a current depressive episode and reports having experienced a similar episode five years ago, with full recovery in between. The presence of more than one depressive episode aligns with the criteria for Recurrent Depressive Disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Major Depressive Disorder: This would be considered if the patient was experiencing their first depressive episode. Since the patient has had a previous depressive episode, the diagnosis is Recurrent Depressive Disorder rather than a single Major Depressive Disorder.

 

Option C. Dysthymia: Also known as Persistent Depressive Disorder, dysthymia is characterized by chronic, mild depressive symptoms that last for at least two years. The patient's symptoms are more severe, consistent with major depressive episodes rather than mild chronic symptoms, which rules out dysthymia.

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: Cyclothymia involves periods of hypomanic symptoms and mild depressive (bipolar) symptoms over at least two years, but the symptoms do not meet the criteria for a full hypomanic episode or a full depressive episode. The patient's presentation does not include any hypomanic symptoms, making cyclothymia an incorrect diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder is diagnosed when a patient experiences two or more major depressive episodes, separated by periods of remission

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has appreciable shortening in her right leg. She is diagnosed with TB Hip. Her presentation will come under which stage? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage III

 

STAGES OF TUBERCULOSIS OF HIP

 

  • Stage 1: 
    • Stage of synovitis
    • FABER (Flexion, Abduction and External rotation)
    • Lengthening
  • Stage 2: 
    • Stage of early arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • <1 cm shortening
  • Stage 3: 
    • Stage of advanced arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • >1 cm shortening
    • Appreciable shortening is a key characteristic.
  • Stage 4: 
    • Stage of subluxation/dislocation
    • Wandering acetabulum or pestle and mortar appearance
  • Stage 5: 
    • Stage of sequelae, ankylosis or severe arthritis

 

 

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

 

 

Additionally,

  • Stage V: Described as a "fused, finished off joint" known as fibrous ankylosis. This stage represents the end progression of certain joint diseases where there is complete fusion of the joint surfaces.
  • In TB affecting peripheral joints, such as the hip and knee, the fusion is more commonly fibrous ankylosis, where the fusion involves more fibrous tissue rather than direct bone fusion. This is painful condition. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I:

  • Known as the stage of synovitis.
  • Characterized by increased capacity of the hip.
  • The position of comfort is FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation).
  • FABER leads to lengthening of the leg, not shortening.

 

Option B. Stage II:

  • Early arthritis stage with joint damage.
  • The lower limb adopts a position of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.
  • Shortening is present but is > 1 cm and not appreciable.

 

Option D. Stage IV:

  • Involves destruction of the bone and changes in the shape of the joint.
  • The femoral head migrates, causing subluxation or dislocation.
  • Known as the stage of the wandering acetabulum, a misnomer for the wandering femoral head.
  • Not specifically associated with the appreciable shortening described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Stage III of TB hip is characterized by late or advanced arthritis with appreciable shortening of the leg (> 1 cm).

questions.text: Where does the maximum water absorption occur within the renal tubules? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCT

 

The Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) is the site where the majority of water reabsorption occurs in the nephron. Approximately 60-65% of the filtered water is reabsorbed in the PCT. This reabsorption is largely due to the active transport of sodium ions, which creates an osmotic gradient that drives water reabsorption.

 

The PCT is highly efficient in reclaiming water, electrolytes, and other essential nutrients from the filtrate, ensuring that the body retains vital substances while excreting waste products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DCT (Distal Convoluted Tubule):  While the DCT does participate in water reabsorption, it does so to a much lesser extent compared to the PCT. The DCT is more involved in the fine-tuning of sodium, potassium, and pH balance.

 

Option C. Loop of Henle:  The Loop of Henle, particularly the descending limb, is permeable to water and contributes to water reabsorption. However, the amount of water reabsorbed here is significantly less than in the PCT.

 

Option D. Collecting duct: The collecting duct is involved in the final concentration of urine and reabsorption of water under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). While it plays a crucial role in water reabsorption, the total volume reabsorbed here is less than in the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) is the site of maximum water absorption within the renal tubules, reabsorbing about 60-65% of the filtered water.

questions.text: As per United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, Targets for MMR and U5MR to be achieved by 2030 are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70 MMR, 25 U5MR

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were established in 2016 as a global agenda to be achieved by 2030. Among the 17 goals outlined, Goal 3 is specifically focused on health and well-being.

 

Under this goal:

 

  • Target 3.1 aims to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
  • Target 3.2 focuses on reducing the under-5 mortality rate (U5MR) to 25 per 1,000 live births and neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births.

 

These targets are part of a broader effort to improve health outcomes and ensure universal health coverage by 2030.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals aim to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to below 70 per 100,000 live births and the under-5 mortality rate to 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lienorenal ligament

 

The structure marked in the image is identified as the lienorenal ligament. The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal ligament that connects the spleen to the left kidney. It is crucial because it contains important structures such as the splenic artery and vein.

 

In the provided image, you can see the vertebra centrally located, with the kidneys visible on each side. The spleen, which lies adjacent to the stomach, is connected to the kidney by the lienorenal ligament. The splenic artery, a branch of the celiac trunk, passes through this ligament.

 

During surgical procedures, especially when ligating the splenic artery, knowledge of this ligament's anatomy is essential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. It contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery. However, in the provided image, the marked structure does not represent this ligament.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum extending from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum. It contains the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct). The marked structure in the image is not the lesser omentum.

 

Option D. Greater omentum: This is a large apron-like fold of visceral peritoneum that hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach. It covers the intestines but is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal structure connecting the spleen to the kidney and contains the splenic artery. This ligament is essential for surgeons to identify, especially during procedures involving the spleen or splenic artery.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance in the kidneys. In this formula:

 

  • U stands for the Urinary concentration of the substance.
  • V stands for the Urinary volume or urinary flow rate.
  • P stands for the Plasma concentration of the substance.

 

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. The UV/P formula is applied to determine how effectively the kidneys are clearing a particular substance from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration Fraction: This is calculated as the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) divided by the Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This process involves the transfer of substances from the blood into the tubular fluid.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This process involves the movement of substances from the tubular fluid back into the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker of carcinoid tumor? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-HIAA

 

Carcinoid tumors originate from enterochromaffin cells, which are rich in serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). Serotonin is metabolized to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine are indicative of a carcinoid tumor, particularly when the tumor is active and producing excessive serotonin. This makes 5-HIAA a reliable tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring carcinoid tumors and the associated carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin is a tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, not carcinoid tumors. It is used to monitor patients with medullary thyroid cancer.

 

Option C. Catecholamine: Catecholamines are associated with adrenal medullary tumors, such as pheochromocytoma. They are not specific for carcinoid tumors.

 

Option D. Dopamine: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter and is not used as a tumor marker for carcinoid tumors. It is associated with different physiological and pathological processes, but not directly with carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinically, patients with carcinoid syndrome may present with a range of symptoms including hepatomegaly, bronchospasm that mimics asthma, episodes of vasoconstriction affecting blood vessels, increased intestinal motility manifesting as diarrhea, and distinctive flushing of the skin. The co-occurrence of symptoms like diarrhea, asthma-like respiratory issues, and hepatomegaly should immediately suggest the possibility of carcinoid syndrome.

 

An increase in the levels of 5-HIAA in blood and urine is a significant indicator (primary tumor marker) of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: Rickets occurs due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D

 

  • Rickets is a skeletal disorder that results from a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. 
  • The primary cause of rickets is a lack of Vitamin D, which is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphate in the body. 
  • Without adequate Vitamin D, bones can become soft and weak.
  • Key features of rickets include:
    • Cupping: The metaphyseal ends of bones become cup-shaped.
    • Splaying: An increase in the width of the metaphyseal ends.
    • Flaring: The ends of the bones point outward.

 

 

  • These characteristics are critical diagnostic features of rickets and help differentiate it from other bone disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to issues like night blindness and impaired immunity.

 

Option B. Vitamin B: B vitamins are crucial for energy production and neurological function. 

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums and joint pain. In vitamin C deficiency, the bony ends appear more white on radiographs (Whitening).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickets is primarily caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, which leads to characteristic bone deformities such as cupping, splaying, and flaring of the metaphyseal ends.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with fever, headaches, myalgia, and drowsiness. Over the next few days, he develops dizziness and altered consciousness. His mother mentions that he consumed palm fruit during a recent trip to Kerala and has felt unwell since then. Based on his symptoms and travel history, which of the following viruses should be considered in your differential diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus that is primarily transmitted from fruit bats to humans through contaminated palm sap or fruit. Kerala, India, has reported several outbreaks of Nipah virus, and the clinical presentation includes fever, headache, myalgia, dizziness, and altered consciousness, which can progress to encephalitis and coma. The consumption of palm fruit in an endemic area raises the suspicion of Nipah virus in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dengue virus: Dengue typically presents with fever, retro-orbital pain, severe myalgia, and rash. However, it does not cause significant central nervous system symptoms like altered consciousness, which is seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Ebola virus: While Ebola can cause fever, myalgia, and severe systemic illness, it is more commonly associated with hemorrhagic symptoms, which this patient does not exhibit. It is also less likely to occur in this geographical setting (Kerala).

 

Option D. Chikungunya virus: Chikungunya presents with fever, rash, and severe joint pain, typically without the central nervous system involvement seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus is transmitted through contact with fruit bats or contaminated palm sap, particularly in areas like Kerala, India. It can cause severe encephalitis, and a travel history to endemic regions should prompt suspicion.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jejunal atresia

 

The image provided shows the classic "triple bubble" sign, which is characteristic of jejunal atresia. In this condition, there are three distinct bubbles visible on the radiograph: the stomach, the proximal duodenum, and the distal duodenum. This occurs because the blockage is located at the level of the jejunum, causing dilatation of the preceding segments of the intestine.

 

Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where a portion of the jejunum is absent or closed, leading to obstruction. This results in the accumulation of air and fluid in the segments of the intestine proximal to the obstruction, creating the appearance of multiple bubbles on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small bowel obstruction: Typically presents with multiple air-fluid levels throughout the bowel, rather than the distinct "bubble" signs seen in jejunal atresia.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Characterized by the "double bubble" sign, where only two bubbles are visible: one in the stomach and one in the proximal duodenum. The third bubble seen in the image rules out duodenal atresia.

 

Option D. CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis): Presents with a single bubble on the radiograph, representing a dilated stomach. The pyloric stenosis prevents stomach contents from passing into the duodenum, leading to a single dilated stomach bubble.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "triple bubble" sign is indicative of jejunal atresia, where three dilated segments are visible on the radiograph: the stomach, proximal duodenum, and distal duodenum. This sign is crucial for differentiating jejunal atresia from other types of intestinal obstructions like duodenal atresia or small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

 

Lignocaine 2% (also known as lidocaine) is the most commonly used local anesthetic for cataract surgery. It provides effective and rapid onset of anesthesia, making it ideal for this type of procedure. Lignocaine is typically used for infiltration anesthesia, which involves injecting the anesthetic around the eye to block nerve impulses.

 

Types of Local Anesthesia:

 

  • Infiltrating Type: This involves injecting the anesthetic directly into the tissue to numb a specific area.
  • Topical: Applied directly to the surface of the skin or mucous membranes. Best drug is proparacain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine 0.5%:  While bupivacaine can be used in ophthalmic surgery, it's generally reserved for cases where longer-lasting anesthesia is required. It's not the first choice for routine cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Prilocaine 0.5%:  Prilocaine is sometimes used in dental procedures but is not commonly used in ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option D. Ropivacaine 0.05%:  Ropivacaine is used in various surgical procedures but is not typically the first choice for cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: The type of cataract associated with blunt trauma is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

 

Rosette cataract is a type of cataract typically associated with blunt trauma to the eye. This type of cataract has a characteristic flower-like appearance, resembling the petals of a rose, hence the name "rosette." Blunt trauma can cause disruption in the lens fibers, leading to the formation of this unique pattern, which can be located either in the anterior or posterior cortex of the lens.

 

 

Vossius ring:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower cataract: Sunflower cataract is seen in patients with Wilson's disease, a disorder of copper metabolism. It is not associated with trauma.

 

 

Option B. Snowflake cataract: Snowflake cataract is typically seen in diabetic patients and is characterized by the presence of multiple small, white opacities in the lens. It is not related to blunt trauma.

 

 

Option D. Christmas tree cataract: Christmas tree cataract is seen in patients with myotonic dystrophy. It presents with brightly colored, polychromatic crystals within the lens, which resemble the decorations on a Christmas tree. This type of cataract is not associated with trauma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosette cataract is the type of cataract that develops following blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by its distinctive flower-like pattern.

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. A preservative was used to preserve his viscera. Which of the following poisoning is seen in it? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aconite

 

The question describes a scenario of sudden death where a preservative was used to preserve the viscera. The key point here is the suspicion of poisoning leading to sudden death. Aconite is a well-known cardiac poison that can cause sudden death by affecting the heart's function. Cardiac poisons such as aconite disrupt normal cardiac activity, leading to fatal arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol poisoning can be fatal, it typically does not cause sudden death in the manner described. The symptoms and progression of alcohol poisoning differ significantly from those of cardiac poisons.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning usually presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity. It is less likely to cause sudden cardiac death compared to aconite.

 

Option D. Thymol: Thymol is an antiseptic and fungicide, not typically associated with poisoning that leads to sudden death. Its toxic effects do not align with the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite is a potent cardiac poison known for causing sudden death due to its severe impact on cardiac function

 

Cardiac poisons: Mnemonic - DHONAQ

 

Digitalis, Hydrogen cyanide, Oleander, Nicotine, Aconite, and Quinine.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 districts to measure the mean blood pressure. Health workers visited each house of the 3 districts. Identify the epidemiological study design. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross sectional study.

 

A cross-sectional study involves collecting data at a single point in time from a population or a representative subset to assess the prevalence of outcomes or characteristics, such as mean blood pressure. In this case, health workers visited each house in the three districts at the same time to measure blood pressure, making it a cross-sectional study. This type of study is also known as a "snapshot study" or "prevalence study" because it provides a picture of the population's health status at one point in time, allowing the calculation of prevalence rates for conditions like hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case control study: This design involves comparing individuals with a particular condition (cases) to those without it (controls) and looking retrospectively to identify exposures. Since the study described is not retrospective and does not involve comparing cases to controls, it is not a case control study.

 

Option C. Cohort study: A cohort study follows a group of individuals over time to see how certain exposures affect outcomes. The study in question does not follow participants over time but rather assesses them at one point in time, ruling out the cohort study design.

 

Option D. Ecological study: An ecological study looks at data at the group or population level rather than individual level, often using existing data. The study described involves direct data collection from individuals, making it unsuitable as an ecological study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cross-sectional study collects data from a population at one point in time, often used to determine the prevalence of a condition like hypertension.

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids followed by FESS

 

Steroids followed by FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): This option is incorrect because steroids and FESS are primarily used for treating chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis. FESS is not an initial management option for CSF rhinorrhea; it is not related to repairing the skull base defect causing the CSF leak.

 

CSF rhinorrhea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose, often due to a defect in the skull base. Initial management focuses on conservative measures to allow spontaneous healing and to prevent complications such as meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bed rest: Advising the patient to take bed rest and avoid activities that increase intracranial pressure is a standard initial approach. This helps reduce the flow of CSF and may allow the defect to heal on its own.

 

Option C. HRCT (High-Resolution CT): HRCT is useful for diagnosing the exact site and cause of the CSF leak. It helps in planning further treatment if conservative measures fail.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and Acetazolamide: Antibiotics are given to prevent infections such as meningitis. Acetazolamide, a diuretic, reduces CSF production and intracranial pressure, which can help reduce the leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child was brought to the emergency with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. He was dehydrated. What should be corrected before performing surgical treatment in this baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The child presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting, which is a classic sign of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). IHPS is a condition in infants causing severe vomiting due to the thickening of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction.

 

Patients with IHPS often develop a specific electrolyte imbalance characterized by hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid), resulting in low chloride levels and secondary metabolic alkalosis. This condition also results in potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Before performing surgical treatment (such as a pyloromyotomy, often referenced in this context as the Ramstedt procedure), it is crucial to correct the electrolyte imbalance to stabilize the patient. The primary focus is on correcting hypokalemia because potassium is essential for normal cellular function and cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This condition involves high potassium levels, which is not typically seen in patients with IHPS. Instead, these patients usually have low potassium levels due to vomiting.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: While hyponatremia (low sodium levels) can occur, it is generally not as significant or immediately life-threatening as hypokalemia in the context of IHPS.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels are not characteristic of IHPS. The vomiting associated with IHPS more commonly leads to losses of electrolytes like potassium and chloride, not an increase in sodium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is often associated with hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Correction of hypokalemia is essential before surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate presents with a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, with protruding intestines exposed directly to the air. Which of the following is the best management approach for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary closure

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the intestines herniate through the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, and are directly exposed to the environment without a protective sac. The ideal management is to perform primary surgical closure to prevent dehydration, infection, and damage to the intestines. This intervention may involve immediate closure of the defect or gradual reduction of the bowel using a silo.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and observe: Waiting without intervention is not appropriate, as exposed intestines are at high risk for complications like infection, dehydration, and ischemia.

 

Option B. IV fluids: While IV fluids are necessary to manage dehydration, they do not address the underlying problem of exposed intestines that need to be surgically managed.

 

Option D. NG tube decompression: Nasogastric tube decompression is often used as an adjunct to manage gastroschisis but does not replace the need for definitive surgical repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary surgical closure is the definitive management for neonates with gastroschisis to protect the exposed intestines from infection and damage. This may be achieved immediately or by gradual reduction using a sterile silo.

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 68%

 

In a standard normal distribution, the data is symmetrically distributed around the mean, forming a bell-shaped curve known as the Gaussian distribution. This distribution is characterized by the following properties:

 

  • The mean, median, and mode of the distribution are equal and located at the center of the curve.
  • The curve is bilaterally symmetrical, meaning if a perpendicular line is drawn from the top of the curve, it divides the graph into two equal halves.

 

One of the key features of a standard normal distribution is that it follows the empirical rule, which states:

 

 

Therefore, the percentage of data values that fall within one standard deviation of the mean in a standard normal distribution is approximately 68%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a standard normal distribution, 68% of the data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: Which menstrual cycle length is abnormal? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) >38 days

 

Explanation:

 

According to the latest FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification, the normal menstrual cycle length ranges from 24 to 38 days. A cycle length exceeding 38 days is considered abnormal and is classified as infrequent or delayed menstruation. Previously, the normal range was considered 21 to 35 days, but this has been updated to reflect a broader range of normal cycle lengths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menstrual cycle abnormalities are categorized based on the frequency of the cycles:

 

  • Frequent cycles: Less than 24 days
  • Normal cycles: 24 to 38 days
  • Infrequent cycles: More than 38 days

 

Understanding these classifications helps in diagnosing and managing menstrual disorders effectively.

questions.text: Location of Bartholin cyst at the vaginal orifice is at? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior 1/3rd

 

Bartholin glands are located at the posterior part of the vaginal introitus. These glands are responsible for secreting mucus to provide lubrication for the vagina. A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland becomes blocked, leading to the accumulation of fluid.

 

  • Location: The Bartholin glands are situated at the lower part of the vaginal opening, specifically at the junction between the posterior one-third and the anterior two-thirds of the labia minora. Thus, when a Bartholin cyst forms, it typically presents at this posterior one-third region of the vaginal orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin cyst is located at the posterior one-third of the vaginal orifice, at the margin of the labia minora and the vaginal introitus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for total intravenous anaesthesia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propofol

 

Propofol is the preferred drug for total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) due to several favorable characteristics. It has a rapid onset and offset, allowing for precise control of anesthetic depth. It also has minimal side effects such as nausea and vomiting, making it suitable for day-care surgeries where quick recovery is desired.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While Ketamine is used for anesthesia, it's primarily known for producing dissociative anesthesia, a state where the patient may appear awake but is disconnected from their surroundings. This makes it less suitable for TIVA compared to Propofol.

 

Option B. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate that was once commonly used for induction of anesthesia. However, its longer duration of action and potential for cardiovascular depression make it less desirable than Propofol for TIVA.

 

Option D. Etomidate: Etomidate is another option for anesthesia induction, especially in patients with cardiovascular concerns due to its minimal impact on the cardiovascular system. However, its association with pain on injection and potential for adrenal suppression limit its use as the primary agent for TIVA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is the drug of choice for total intravenous anesthesia and day-care surgery due to its rapid onset and offset, and favorable side effect profile.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and tiredness. He had low Hb and reticulocyte count. BM reveals a decrease in erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pure red cell aplasia

 

Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a selective decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to a significant reduction in red blood cells (RBCs), while white blood cells (WBCs) and platelets remain unaffected.
