This leads to an elevated hematocrit and hemoglobin concentration without an actual increase in the total number of red blood cells. The condition is termed "relative polycythemia" because the increase in RBC concentration is relative to the decreased plasma volume rather than an absolute increase in RBC production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absolute polycythemia: Absolute polycythemia refers to a true increase in the total red blood cell mass. This can occur due to primary polycythemia (polycythemia vera) or secondary polycythemia due to chronic hypoxia or erythropoietin-secreting tumors.

 

Option C. Severe internal bleeding: Severe internal bleeding would typically lead to a decrease in RBC mass and hematocrit, not an increase.

 

Option D. Myeloproliferative disorder: Myeloproliferative disorders are a group of conditions that involve the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow, such as polycythemia vera. These disorders lead to absolute, not relative, polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaisböck syndrome is a form of relative polycythemia caused by a reduction in plasma volume, often due to dehydration, leading to an apparent increase in red blood cell concentration.

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. This condition leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neurons, which can be observed as a cherry red spot in the macula of the retina. However, unlike other sphingolipidoses, Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fabry's disease: Fabry's disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-Galactosidase and is an X-linked recessive disorder. This condition does not typically present with a cherry red spot and is associated with other symptoms such as angiokeratomas and renal complications.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme β-Glucosidase. It is typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly, and while cherry red spots can rarely be seen, it is not a common feature of the disease. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly distinguishes it from Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Option D. Von Gierke disease: Von Gierke disease (Glycogen storage disease type I) is not a lysosomal storage disorder or a sphingolipidosis. It is associated with glycogen metabolism and does not present with cherry red spots. This disease also features hepatomegaly, which is not consistent with the condition described in the question.

 

Additional Information

 

  • All sphingolipidoses are autosomal recessive except for Fabry's disease, which is X-linked recessive.
  • All sphingolipidoses are associated with mental retardation except for Gaucher's disease and Fabry's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have hepatosplenomegaly except for Tay-Sachs and Krabbe's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have a cherry red spot in the eye except for Fabry's and Gaucher's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses with angiokeratoma include GM1 gangliosidosis and Fabry's disease.
  • Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling rheumatoid arthritis or idiopathic juvenile arthritis include Farber's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling sickle cell crisis include Fabry's disease.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.

 

Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following comes under ASA grade 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Healthy patient

 

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is a system used to assess the fitness of patients before surgery. It classifies patients into six different categories based on their overall health:

 

  • ASA 1: A Normal, healthy patient with no systemic disease and no significant medical problems.
  • ASA 2: A patient with mild systemic disease that does not limit physical activity (e.g., mild asthma or controlled hypertension).
  • ASA 3: A patient with severe systemic disease that limits activity but is not incapacitating (e.g., uncontrolled diabetes or hypertension).
  • ASA 4: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (e.g., unstable angina, advanced COPD).
  • ASA 5: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without surgery (e.g., massive trauma, ruptured aneurysm).
  • ASA 6: A brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

 

In this classification, ASA grade 1 is designated for a healthy patient with no significant medical problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mild disease: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 2 patient, who has a mild systemic disease that is under control and does not significantly impact their overall health.

 

Option C. Moderate disease: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 3 patient, who has a moderate to severe systemic disease that limits their activity.

 

Option D. Morbid patient: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 5 patient, who is moribund and at a high risk of death without surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:


ASA grade 1 refers to a normal, healthy patient with no comorbidities or systemic diseases.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of rivaroxaban is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xa inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that works by inhibiting Factor Xa, a crucial enzyme in the blood coagulation cascade. The name "rivaroxaban" itself hints at its mechanism of action, where "Xa" refers to Factor Xa, and "ban" suggests inhibition. By inhibiting Factor Xa, rivaroxaban prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, thus reducing the formation of fibrin clots. This inhibition is crucial in preventing and treating conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and reducing the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.

 

Other Xa blocker drugs: Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IIa inhibitor: IIa refers to thrombin (Factor IIa), and while inhibiting thrombin is another anticoagulation strategy, rivaroxaban does not act on Factor IIa. Instead, drugs like dabigatran work as direct thrombin inhibitors.

 

Option C. Vitamin K antagonist: This refers to a different class of anticoagulants, such as warfarin, which inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Rivaroxaban does not affect vitamin K or its associated pathways.

 

Option D. Antithrombin activation: Antithrombin activation is the mechanism of action for drugs like heparin. Rivaroxaban does not work by activating antithrombin but rather by directly inhibiting Factor Xa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct, reversible inhibitor of Factor Xa, a key enzyme in the blood coagulation process, and is used as an anticoagulant.

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Plasmodium falciparum is identified in the peripheral smear by the presence of multiple rings within a single red blood cell (RBC) and the characteristic headphone-like structure known as the accolé form or appliqué form. In the provided image, multiple rings are visible in some RBCs, and a distinctive headphone-like structure can be observed, which are hallmarks of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium vivax: This species typically shows a single ring per RBC and can form larger, amoeboid shapes in the late trophozoite stage, which are not seen in this image.

 

Option C. Plasmodium ovale: This species also shows a single ring per RBC and is often characterized by an oval shape of the infected RBC and ragged cell edges, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Plasmodium malariae: This species shows a band form of the trophozoite across the RBC, which is not present in the image. It also typically has fewer merozoites in the schizont stage compared to Plasmodium falciparum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest marker for myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Ischemia-modified albumin (IMA) is considered one of the earliest markers for myocardial infarction (MI). It can be detected in the blood within minutes of ischemia and before any significant myocardial necrosis occurs.

 

The novelty of IMA lies in its ability to indicate ischemia even before traditional markers like CK-MB or Troponin I rise, making it particularly useful in the early diagnosis of MI. Its primary utility, however, is in its negative predictive value—if IMA levels are normal, it's more likely that the patient is not experiencing an MI.

 

Additionally,

 

Heart Fatty Acid Binding Protein (H-FABP), one more novel early marker is noted for its rapid response following myocardial injury. It can be detected early in the blood after the onset of a heart attack, making it a valuable tool for early diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK-MB: CK-MB is a marker of myocardial injury that typically rises within 3-4 hours after the onset of infarction.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase 1 (LDH 1): LDH 1 is a late marker of myocardial infarction, typically rising 24-48 hours after the onset.

 

Note - LDH reacts with Triphenyl Tetrazole Chloride dye, which is used to visually differentiate between normal and infarcted cardiac tissue during diagnostic procedures. In the presence of this dye, normal cardiac tissue produces a big red color, while infarcted areas show a yellowish appearance. This color differentiation helps in identifying and assessing the extent of myocardial damage.

 

Option C. Cardiac Troponin I: Cardiac Troponins, especially Troponin I, are highly specific for myocardial injury and are the gold standard for diagnosing MI. However, they typically rise within 4-6 hours after the onset, making them less useful as the earliest marker compared to IMA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin (IMA) is an early biomarker for myocardial infarction, detectable shortly after ischemia begins, and is particularly valuable for its ability to rule out MI when levels are normal.

choices.text: Non vigorous baby
Rh negative mother

questions.text: When should early cord clamping be done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non vigorous baby

 

Early cord clamping should be done primarily when the baby is non-vigorous/ hypoxic baby i.e. not breathing, or not crying at birth. Immediate neonatal resuscitation is required in such cases to address the baby's urgent need for oxygen and support.

 

Delaying cord clamping in a non-vigorous baby could waste crucial time needed for resuscitation efforts. According to WHO guidelines, the only absolute contraindication to delayed cord clamping is a non-vigorous baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rh negative mother: Although older guidelines suggested early cord clamping in Rh-negative mothers to reduce the risk of fetomaternal hemorrhage, current guidelines do not strongly recommend this practice. The benefits of delayed cord clamping, such as reducing anemia in the baby, outweigh the potential risks.

 

Option C. Preterm: For preterm babies, delayed cord clamping is recommended to help prevent anemia and improve blood volume. Preterm infants benefit significantly from the additional blood received during delayed clamping.

 

Option D. Pre-eclampsia: Pre-eclampsia is not a contraindication for delayed cord clamping. Delayed clamping can still provide the newborn with additional blood and help prevent anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early cord clamping is indicated for non-vigorous babies who require immediate resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: A 65-year-old PLHIV patient came with cough, fever, and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV

 

In the biopsy image, the characteristic feature to note is the presence of inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm of the cell, giving an appearance often described as "owl eye." This is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV can cause severe infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as patients living with HIV (PLHIV). The virus leads to the formation of large cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause pneumonia, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not produce the distinctive "owl eye" inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. EBV: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is known for causing infectious mononucleosis and is associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders, but there is no inclusion bodies in the cells.

 

Option D. HSV2: Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2) can cause various infections, including pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, but it does not produce the specific "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of "owl eye" inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells in a biopsy is indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those living with HIV.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with breathlessness and cough. His recent CD4 count was less than 200 and the patient’s chest X-ray is shown. BAL was done and reports are pending. What is the likely diagnosis and treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocystis jiroveci; Cotrimoxazole

 

The patient, an HIV-positive individual with a CD4 count of less than 200, presents with symptoms of breathlessness and cough. The chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. These findings are highly suggestive of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), also known as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). This condition is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV infection.

 

The standard treatment for PJP is cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucor; Amphotericin B: Mucormycosis typically presents with necrotizing infection of the sinuses, brain, or lungs, often in diabetic or immunocompromised patients, but it does not typically present with the bilateral infiltrates seen in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Aspergillus; Voriconazole: Aspergillosis often presents with focal infiltrates or cavitations rather than diffuse bilateral infiltrates. It is also less common in patients with HIV compared to PJP.

 

Option D. Candida; Fluconazole: Pulmonary candidiasis is rare and usually occurs in severely immunocompromised patients, often presenting with multiple nodular infiltrates rather than the diffuse pattern seen in PJP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an HIV patient with a CD4 count less than 200, presenting with breathlessness and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, the likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), and the treatment of choice is cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mite

 

The boy's symptoms, including severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in specific body areas (intertriginous regions, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits), are classic signs of scabies. Scabies is a skin condition caused by infestation with the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The mite burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, especially at night. The areas affected (often referred to as the circle of Hebra) are characteristic for scabies.

 

 

Circle of Hebra

 

 

Mites

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice infestation, known as pediculosis, typically causes itching but does not present with burrows in the skin or nocturnal itching. Lice infest hair and clothing rather than burrowing into the skin.

 

Option B. Tick: Ticks are ectoparasites that attach to the skin and can transmit various diseases, such as Lyme disease. However, they do not cause the characteristic burrows or intense nocturnal itching seen in scabies.

 

Option D. Flea: Flea bites cause itchy red spots, primarily on the lower legs, but fleas do not burrow into the skin or cause the described distribution of burrows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wire Speculum

 

The instrument shown in the image is a wire speculum. It is characterized by its wire-like structure with two loops at the ends and a central hinge mechanism. Wire specula are commonly used in ophthalmic surgeries such as cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery, and pterygium surgery. Their primary function is to keep the eyelids apart, providing clear access to the eye during procedures. The surgeon squeezes the instrument to open it, places it between the eyelids, and then releases it to hold the lids open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lid Clamp:  Incorrect. A lid clamp has a different structure, typically with flat surfaces for gripping the eyelid during lid surgeries like entropion or ectropion repairs.
 

 

Option C. Lid Retractor: Incorrect. A lid retractor usually has a plate-like structure at the front and a handle, used for procedures requiring broader lid retraction.

 

 

Option D. Cat's Paw Retractor: Incorrect. This instrument has a fork-like structure at the end and is commonly used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wire speculum is a key instrument in ophthalmic surgery, used to keep the eyelids open and provide access to the eye during various procedures. Its characteristic wire-like structure with loops at the ends distinguishes it from other lid manipulation instruments.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her physician complaining of itching and discomfort in her vaginal area for the past week. She reports thick, curdy white discharge but denies any foul smell. She has been on antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. A wet mount preparation using KOH shows gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Candida albicans

 

Candida albicans is a yeast-like fungus that normally inhabits the skin and mucous membranes but can cause infection in immunocompromised individuals or under conditions that disturb the normal flora, such as recent antibiotic use. Vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC) is a common manifestation, characterized by thick, curdy white vaginal discharge, itching, and burning. Candida produces pseudohyphae, which can be seen on wet mount microscopy with KOH preparation. The vaginal pH is typically less than 4.5 in these infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas vaginalis: This protozoan infection typically presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge, often accompanied by a foul odor. The vaginal pH is elevated, usually greater than 4.5, and the organism is seen as motile on wet mount microscopy.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is caused by an imbalance in vaginal flora, often with overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis. The hallmark discharge is thin, gray-white, and foul-smelling, with a vaginal pH greater than 4.5. Clue cells, not yeast or pseudohyphae, are seen on wet mount.

 

Option D. Gardnerella vaginalis: This is one of the organisms implicated in bacterial vaginosis, presenting with thin, foul-smelling, gray-white discharge. Clue cells on microscopy and a positive "whiff test" with KOH are characteristic findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvovaginal candidiasis caused by Candida albicans presents with curdy white discharge, itching, and burning. Microscopy shows gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. The pH remains <4.5, distinguishing it from other vaginal infections like bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of ptosis and diplopia that worsens with activity and improves with rest. What is the most sensitive investigation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) EMG (Electromyography)

 

The symptoms of ptosis and diplopia that worsen with activity and improve with rest are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder caused by autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

 

The most sensitive investigation for myasthenia gravis is single fiber electromyography (SF-EMG), which detects abnormalities in the neuromuscular transmission by measuring the electrical activity of muscle fibers. Even if single fiber EMG is not specifically mentioned, standard EMG is still highly sensitive and appropriate for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. Another practical test used is repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS), which shows a decremental response in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT scan chest: This is usually performed in confirmed myasthenia gravis patients to rule out thymoma, but it is not the most sensitive test for diagnosing the condition itself.

 

Option C. Acetylcholinesterase test: Also known as the edrophonium test or Tensilon test, this can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving muscle strength. However, it has variable sensitivity and specificity and is less sensitive than EMG.

 

Option D. Nerve conduction velocity: This test is more relevant in the diagnosis of neuropathies, particularly demyelinating neuropathies, where conduction velocities are decreased. It is not the most sensitive test for myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most sensitive investigation for diagnosing myasthenia gravis is electromyography (EMG), particularly single fiber EMG, which detects abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.

questions.text: A baby who can ride a tricycle, can walk alternate steps on stairs, he cannot do hopping. What is the age of the baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.5 years

 

A 3-year-old child can typically ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet. The ability to ride a tricycle is usually developed around the age of 3, as "tri" refers to three, indicating this milestone. Walking up stairs with alternate feet is another skill that a 3-year-old can manage. However, hopping on one foot usually develops around the age of 4. Since the child in question cannot hop yet, it indicates the child is likely not yet 4 years old. Therefore, the best answer is 3.5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child who can ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet but cannot hop is typically around 3.5 years old.

questions.text: Which of the following psychological coping strategies is not considered a defense mechanism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Replacement

 

Defense mechanisms are unconscious psychological strategies used by individuals to cope with reality and maintain self-image. Among the options provided, rationalization, displacement, and regression are well-known defense mechanisms.

 

However, Replacement is not considered a recognized psychological defense mechanism. The term "replacement" might refer to various coping strategies or processes, but it is not classified as a defense mechanism in psychological theory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rationalization: This is a defense mechanism where individuals create a seemingly logical reason for irrational or unacceptable behaviors or feelings to avoid the true explanation.

 

Option B. Displacement: This defense mechanism allows a person to transfer feelings or reactions from the original object or person to a safer substitute. For example, someone angry at their boss might instead take out their frustration on a family member.

 

Option C. Regression: This occurs when an individual faced with stress retreats to an earlier developmental stage. For instance, an adult under stress might start behaving like a child, engaging in activities or behaviors typical of a younger age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Replacement" is not classified as a defense mechanism, whereas rationalization, displacement, and regression are recognized defense mechanisms used to protect oneself from anxiety or unacceptable impulses.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the detection of monkeypox? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PCR

 

The standard technique for the detection of monkeypox is Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). PCR is a molecular technique used to amplify and detect the DNA of the orthopoxvirus, which includes the monkeypox virus. This method is highly sensitive and specific, making it the preferred choice for diagnosing monkeypox. PCR can detect the presence of orthopoxvirus DNA in various clinical specimens, providing a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While an IgM ELISA test can detect antibodies against monkeypox and can become positive about 5 to 8 days after infection, it is not the primary method for initial detection of the virus itself.

 

Option C. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not typically used for the detection of viral DNA in the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Option D. Hemagglutination: This assay is used to detect the ability of viruses to agglutinate red blood cells. It is not commonly used for the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective and standard method for the detection of monkeypox is PCR, which detects the DNA of the orthopoxvirus in clinical specimens.

questions.text: A person who at the time of commission of the offense was of unsound mind, is exempt if he didn't know the nature of the act or its consequences. This rule is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McNaughton rule

 

The McNaughton rule, also known as the legal test or right-wrong test, is the standard used in India to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if, at the time of the commission of the offense, they were suffering from a mental disorder that rendered them incapable of understanding the nature of their act or knowing that it was wrong. This rule emphasizes the individual's ability to understand the act, rather than their ability to control their behavior.

 

The rule is codified in Indian law under Section 84 Indian Penal Code (IPC) (Now, 22 BNS) and has been the primary standard for assessing the criminal liability of mentally ill offenders in India. If a person can understand that their actions are wrong, they are held responsible; otherwise, they are not.

 

Additional Information

 

Various rules related to the criminal responsibility of mentally ill individuals:

 

  • McNaughten Rule: This is a legal test that focuses on whether the person knew right from wrong at the time of the offense. This is also referenced in Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
  • Irresistible Impulse Test: Indicates that a person is not responsible if they acted on an uncontrollable impulse despite knowing the act was wrong.
  • Durham Rule: A person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act was the product of a mental disease or defect.
  • Currens Rule: States that a person is not responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform to the requirements of the law.
  • American Law of Institute Test: A person is not responsible if they lacked:
    • Adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of their conduct due to a mental disease or defect (cognitive insanity).
    • Adequate capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of law (volitional insanity).
  • Doctrine of Partial Responsibility: This implies that while a person may be responsible, their mental illness is considered as a mitigating factor, potentially leading to reduced culpability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Durham's rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act was the product of mental disease or defect. It focuses on the presence of a mental disease or defect as the cause of the unlawful act, rather than the individual's understanding of the nature of the act.

 

Option C. Currens rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of the law due to mental illness. It emphasizes the individual's ability to conform their behavior to legal standards.

 

Option D. Irresistible impulse test: This test states that an individual is not criminally responsible if, due to mental illness, they were unable to control their actions or resist the impulse to commit the act, even if they understood the nature of the act and that it was wrong.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the McNaughton rule is used to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if they were unable to understand the nature of their act or know that it was wrong due to their mental condition.

questions.text: Name the hormone secreted by the marked cell: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitonin

 

The marked cells in the histology image are parafollicular cells, also known as C cells, located in the thyroid gland. These cells are found outside the thyroid follicles, which are filled with colloid. Parafollicular cells are responsible for secreting the hormone calcitonin.

 

Calcitonin plays a crucial role in calcium homeostasis by lowering blood calcium levels when they are too high. It achieves this by inhibiting osteoclast activity in bones, which decreases the release of calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenaline: Adrenaline is secreted by the adrenal medulla, not by the cells in the thyroid gland. Therefore, it is not related to the marked cells in the image.

 

Option C. Prolactin: Prolactin is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and is involved in milk production in the mammary glands. It is not secreted by the thyroid gland or its parafollicular cells.

 

Option D. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is secreted by the follicular cells of the thyroid gland, not the parafollicular cells. The marked cells in the image are outside the follicles and are responsible for calcitonin secretion, not thyroxine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parafollicular cells (C cells) in the thyroid gland secrete calcitonin, a hormone that helps regulate calcium levels in the blood.

choices.text: Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother
Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm

questions.text: Ventouse is contra-indicated in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preterm

 

Ventouse (vacuum extraction) is contraindicated in preterm deliveries due to the increased risk of neonatal complications. The head of a preterm baby is more vulnerable to injury, and the use of vacuum can lead to severe complications such as neurological damage, cephalohematoma, or skull fractures. This is because the vacuum exerts force on the baby’s head, which is particularly fragile in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother: This is not an absolute contraindication for vacuum delivery. In fact, vacuum extraction is often used when there are decreased maternal efforts during the second stage of labor.

 

Option B. Heart disease: Maternal heart disease is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction. However, it may influence the choice of delivery method to minimize maternal stress.

 

Option D. Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm: While full cervical dilation (10 cm) is ideal for vacuum extraction, it is a relative contraindication rather than an absolute one. In urgent situations where cesarean section is not feasible, vacuum extraction might still be considered even if the cervix is not fully dilated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absolute Contraindication of Ventouse:

 

  • Preterm
  • Face presentation
  • After coming head of the breech
  • IUD

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding increase in GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase renal perfusion

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is influenced by various factors, including the blood flow through the kidneys and the pressures within the glomerular capillaries. An increase in renal perfusion means an increase in blood flow to the kidneys, which enhances the filtration process and thereby increases the GFR. This can be achieved by dilation of the afferent arteriole (which increases blood flow into the glomerulus) or by constriction of the efferent arteriole (which increases the pressure within the glomerulus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase resistance of afferent arteriole: Increasing the resistance of the afferent arteriole means constricting it, which would reduce blood flow into the glomerulus and subsequently decrease the GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease resistance of efferent arteriole: Decreasing the resistance of the efferent arteriole means dilating it, allowing blood to flow out of the glomerulus more easily. This reduces the pressure within the glomerulus, leading to a decrease in GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increasing the hydrostatic pressure within the Bowman's capsule would oppose the filtration pressure, leading to a decrease in GFR rather than an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing renal perfusion is the most effective way to increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with sensory disturbances, including a lack of awareness of joint position (conscious proprioception). Which of the following pathways is responsible for carrying conscious proprioceptive information? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dorsal column fibers

 

The dorsal column-medial lemniscus (DCML) pathway carries signals related to conscious proprioception, as well as fine touch, vibration, and pressure. These fibers originate from the sensory receptors, enter the dorsal column of the spinal cord, and then ascend ipsilaterally to the medulla. The pathway includes two divisions: the fasciculus gracilis (for the lower body) and the fasciculus cuneatus (for the upper body).

 

Upon reaching the medulla, the fibers synapse and cross to the contralateral side before continuing to the thalamus, eventually terminating in the sensory cortex for conscious processing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior spinothalamic tract: This tract is part of the anterolateral system, which carries signals related to crude touch.

 

Option C. Lateral spinothalamic tract: This pathway transmits signals of pain and temperature, also part of the anterolateral system.

 

Option D. Vestibular tract: This pathway is involved in the coordination of balance and equilibrium, not proprioception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conscious proprioception is carried by the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, which conveys fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the body to the brain.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female who had a lumbar puncture continues to have a headache. Which of the following is not recommended? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluid restriction

 

The patient is experiencing a post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), which can occur after a lumbar puncture due to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). This type of headache is typically treated with a variety of supportive measures to alleviate symptoms and promote healing.

 

Fluid restriction is not recommended for patients with PDPH.  In fact, liberal fluid intake is advised to help replace the lost CSF and maintain adequate hydration, which can aid in reducing the headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low volume blood patch: An epidural blood patch is an effective treatment for PDPH, particularly in refractory cases. It involves injecting a small amount of the patient's own blood into the epidural space to seal the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Increase caffeine: Caffeine is known to help reduce the severity of PDPH due to its vasoconstrictive properties, which can help alleviate the headache.

 

Option D. Stool softeners: Stool softeners are recommended to prevent straining during bowel movements, which can exacerbate the headache. Constipation is common in postoperative patients due to the use of anesthetics and other medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of post-dural puncture headache, fluid restriction is not recommended. Instead, measures such as epidural blood patches, increased caffeine intake, and stool softeners are utilized to manage symptoms and promote recovery.

questions.text: Benzathine penicillin is given for the treatment of rheumatic fever. This is which level of prevention? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary level

 

Secondary prevention involves the early detection and treatment of a disease to prevent its progression.

 

In the context of rheumatic fever, if a child has already developed the condition, benzyl benzathine penicillin (BBP) is administered to prevent further complications, such as rheumatic heart disease. This treatment is given in regular doses (1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; every 3 weeks) over a period of 5 years or until the child is 18 years old, whichever comes later. This approach is aimed at treating the condition and preventing its worsening, which characterizes secondary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial level: This level focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in a population. It is not relevant to the treatment of an existing condition like rheumatic fever.

 

Option B. Primary level: This involves preventing the onset of disease in at-risk individuals. In this context, primary prevention would involve giving penicillin to prevent the initial occurrence of rheumatic fever in a child with a streptococcal sore throat.

 

Dose of BBP - 1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; single dose; IM stat.

 

Option D. Tertiary level: Tertiary prevention is aimed at reducing the impact of an ongoing illness that has lasting effects. This would involve rehabilitation and managing chronic complications, which is not the primary aim of benzathine penicillin treatment in rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary prevention involves the treatment of existing conditions, such as rheumatic fever, to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A case of accidental burn injuries in a female patient aged 35 years involving right upper limb, entire right lower limb, entire front and back of abdomen. Which of the following is the percentage of burn injuries according to the rule of nine? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45%

 

The rule of nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. According to this rule, the body is divided into sections that represent approximately 9% (or multiples of 9%) of the TBSA.

 

  • Right upper limb: Each upper limb is 9% (4.5% for the front and 4.5% for the back).
  • Right lower limb: Each lower limb is 18% (9% for the front and 9% for the back).
  • Entire front and back of the abdomen: The anterior trunk (front) and the posterior trunk (back) together make up 18% (9% for the front and 9% for the back).

 

 

Calculating the total percentage of burn injuries:

 

  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right lower limb: 18%
  • Entire front and back of the abdomen: 18%

 

Therefore, the total percentage of burn injuries is:

 

9% (upper limb) + 18% (lower limb) + 18% (abdomen) = 45%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with pinpoint bruises around his hair follicles and refuses to move his legs due to pain. He also has tender, raised nodules along his rib cage, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scurvy

 

Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis. Without sufficient vitamin C, there is defective collagen formation, leading to fragile blood vessels and impaired bone development. Key features include:

 

  • Pinpoint bruising around hair follicles (perifollicular hemorrhages)
  • Tender, raised nodules along the rib cage (scorbutic rosary) due to costochondral separation
  • Painful limbs and refusal to walk, often due to subperiosteal hemorrhages
  • Generalized bleeding tendencies due to weakened capillaries

 

The child’s refusal to move, coupled with the classic scorbutic rosary and pinpoint bruising, strongly suggests scurvy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute osteomyelitis: This condition presents with fever, localized bone pain, and inflammation. While scurvy can mimic osteomyelitis due to subperiosteal hemorrhages causing bone pain, the absence of systemic signs like fever makes osteomyelitis less likely.

 

Option B. Osteogenesis imperfecta: This is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones and frequent fractures due to defective collagen synthesis. The absence of fractures and the presence of other scurvy-specific symptoms, such as pinpoint bruising and costochondral separation, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Rickets: Rickets is caused by a vitamin D deficiency and is characterized by bone deformities, including bowing of the legs and a rachitic rosary (non-painful costochondral nodules). Unlike scurvy, the nodules in rickets are painless and the child does not have bruising or the same pain pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy, due to vitamin C deficiency, presents with perifollicular hemorrhages, painful limb movements, and tender nodules (scorbutic rosary). Diagnosis is clinical, supported by dietary history, and treated with vitamin C supplementation.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure often seen in aplastic anemia, involves the failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells. The spleen is not involved in this pathology, so splenectomy would not be beneficial. The problem lies within the bone marrow, not the spleen, making splenectomy contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is commonly indicated in cases of splenic rupture, whether due to trauma or iatrogenic causes, to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: In cases of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), splenectomy can be an effective treatment option to achieve durable remission, although it is not the first-line treatment.

 

  • Corticosteroids and other treatments are often tried first.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in hairy cell leukemia in cases of massive splenomegaly or persistent cytopenias to alleviate symptoms and improve blood counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text: The defined population norm for Urban-Primary health centre in our country is one such centre per: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 per 50,000

 

In India, the population norm for establishing a UPHC is one center per 50,000 population. These centers are intended to provide primary healthcare services in urban areas, addressing the healthcare needs of urban populations efficiently.

 

The UPHCs are equipped to deliver a range of health services, including preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative care.

 

In UPHC, one Urban Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) per 10,000 population, and one Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) per 1,000 to 2,500 population.

 

Remember –

 

Population norm for rural PHC

 

  • 1 per 30,000 populations in plain area
  • 1 per 20,000 populations in tribal and hilly areas

 

Educational Objective:

 

The population norm for establishing an Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) in India is one center per 50,000 populations.

questions.text: Pneumoconiosis associated with exposure to cotton dust is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Byssinosis.

 

Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease," is a type of pneumoconiosis specifically associated with exposure to cotton dust. It is an occupational lung disease that typically affects workers in the textile industry, including those involved in spinning, weaving, and processing cotton. The inhalation of cotton dust can cause the airways to become constricted, leading to symptoms such as chest tightness, coughing, and wheezing, particularly at the start of the workweek, which is sometimes referred to as "Monday fever."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bagassosis: This is a pneumoconiosis caused by exposure to bagasse, the fibrous material left over after sugarcane or sorghum stalks are crushed to extract their juice. It is commonly seen in workers in the sugar industry.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Also known as "black lung disease," this condition is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. It primarily affects coal miners and results in the accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like cement, glass manufacturing, and stone cutting. It leads to inflammation and scarring in the lungs.

 

Note –

 

Asbestosis: Caused by exposure to asbestos dust, asbestosis is a serious condition that leads to lung fibrosis. It is prevalent among workers in the cement industry and is particularly noted in shipyard workers due to the historical use of asbestos in ship construction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of Pneumoconiosis:

questions.text: In a drowning case, primary relaxation is seen in all muscles except one group of muscles. What is this condition known as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cadaveric spasm

 

Typically, after death, there is a phase of primary relaxation in all muscles, followed by the onset of rigor mortis (stiffening of muscles). This primary relaxation phase usually lasts for about two hours. However, in certain cases, such as intense emotional or physical stress before death, cadaveric spasm can occur.

 

Cadaveric spasm, also known as instantaneous rigor, occurs immediately after death without any preceding relaxation phase. This condition is most commonly seen in the muscles of the hands and forearms. In the context of drowning, the hands may grasp objects such as grass or mud, reflecting the struggle for survival, and these objects may still be clutched post-mortem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs several hours after death, following a period of primary relaxation. It affects all muscles sequentially and is not specific to any particular group of muscles immediately post-death.

 

Option C. Pugilistic attitude: The pugilistic attitude is a posture that results from the coagulation and contraction of muscles due to exposure to intense heat, such as in fire victims. It resembles a boxer's stance and is unrelated to drowning or primary muscle relaxation.

 

Option D. Washerwoman hand: Washerwoman hand refers to the wrinkling of the skin on the hands and feet after prolonged immersion in water. It is not related to muscle relaxation or contraction but rather to skin changes due to water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm occurs immediately after death without a phase of relaxation and is typically seen in the muscles of the hands, often indicating a struggle before death.

questions.text: 65-year-old lady with a history of COPD and cor pulmonale presents with breathlessness and frequent exacerbations. Which of the following will improve survival in this patient?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long-term O2 therapy

 

For patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there are only a few interventions proven to improve survival. These include smoking cessation, long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) for those who qualify, and lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) in selected patients. LTOT is particularly beneficial for patients with severe hypoxemia, as it helps maintain adequate oxygen levels, reducing the risk of heart failure and other complications associated with chronic hypoxemia.

 

In this case, the presence of cor pulmonale, which is a condition secondary to long-standing COPD leading to right heart failure, further strengthens the indication for LTOT. This therapy can help manage symptoms and prevent further deterioration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulization with budesonide: While this may help in managing symptoms of COPD by reducing inflammation and preventing exacerbations, it does not have a proven impact on improving overall survival.

 

Option C. Pneumococcal vaccine: This can reduce the risk of pneumococcal infections, which are common in COPD patients, but it does not directly improve survival in the long-term management of COPD.

 

Option D. Positive Pressure Ventilation:  This can be useful in managing acute exacerbations of COPD or chronic respiratory failure, but it is not typically used as a long-term therapy to improve survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is one of the few interventions that improve survival in patients with COPD, especially those with severe hypoxemia and complications like cor pulmonale.

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery plays a crucial role in embryonic development, particularly in forming structures related to the circulatory system. On the left side, the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery develops into the ductus arteriosus, a vital fetal blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the lungs, which are not yet functional before birth. After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arch of aorta: The arch of the aorta is primarily derived from the left 4th pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Option C. Subclavian artery: The right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th pharyngeal arch artery and other structures, while the left subclavian artery arises from the left 7th intersegmental artery.

 

Option D. Common carotid artery: The common carotid artery primarily arises from the 3rd pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: The Honorable Supreme Court of India has banned one of the following, which is infamous among doctors for sexual assault cases: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Two finger test

 

The Supreme Court of India has banned the two-finger test, which was infamous in sexual assault cases. The rationale behind the test was that by inserting two fingers into the vagina, the examiner could determine if a woman was "habituated to sex." If two fingers could be inserted, it was assumed that the woman was sexually active; if only one finger could be inserted, it suggested that she was not.

 

This test was criticized for several reasons:

 

  1. Irrelevance to the Current Case: The past sexual behavior of the victim has no bearing on the facts of the current case of sexual assault. The test does not provide any information relevant to determining whether a rape occurred.
  2. Character Judgment: The test was used to infer the character of the woman, which is derogatory and not permissible. It essentially judged the woman based on her sexual history, which is irrelevant and discriminatory.
  3. Psychological Harm: The test could cause additional trauma to the victim, compounding the psychological harm already experienced due to the assault.

 

The Supreme Court's ruling emphasized that the past sexual behavior of a woman should not be documented or examined as it has no relevance to the current case of rape. The focus should be on the incident in question, not on the victim's sexual history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheter insertion: This is a medical procedure used to drain the bladder and is unrelated to assessing sexual history or assault.

 

Option B. Colposcopy: This is a medical diagnostic procedure to examine an illuminated, magnified view of the cervix and the tissues of the vagina and vulva. It is used in cases of abnormal Pap smears and is not used for determining past sexual behavior.

 

Option C. PV speculum: The use of a speculum is part of a gynecological exam to inspect the vaginal and cervical areas. It is a routine medical examination tool and does not relate to assessing sexual history or habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The two-finger test, previously used to assess whether a woman was "habituated to sex," has been banned by the Supreme Court of India due to its irrelevance, discriminatory nature, and potential to cause additional trauma to sexual assault victims.

questions.text: Recommended minimum per capita space for a factory worker as per The Factory Act 1948 is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 500 cu feet

 

The Factory Act of 1948 is a key piece of legislation in India that governs the working conditions in factories. The recommended minimum per capita space for a factory worker according to this act is 500 cubic feet. This requirement is essential to ensure adequate ventilation and prevent the spread of communicable diseases, as well as to improve overall working conditions.

 

The Factories Act, 1948

 

  • Scope: The Act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more persons where power is used and 20 or more persons where power is not used
  • Work related norms:
    • Employment of young persons:
      • Employment prohibited for age less than 14 years
      • 15-18 years old adolescents to be declared fit by ‘certifying surgeons’; will work only between 6AM to 7PM
      • Employment prohibited in certain dangerous occupations
    • Hours of work:
      • A maximum of 4½ hours of work per day for adolescents
      • 48 hours per week (9 hrs per day)
      • Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime)
    • Leave with wages:
      • 1 day per 15 days of work for adolescents
      • Leaves can be accumulated up to 40 days
    • Health, Safety and Welfare recommendations:
      • A minimum of 500 cubic feet space per worker
      • 1 Safety Officer per 1000 workers
      • 1 Welfare Officer per 500 workers
      • 1 Canteen for greater than 250 workers
      • 1 Crèche for greater than 30 women workers
    • Under Factories Act 1948, there are 29 diseases which are notifiable (Schedule 3): Silicosis; Anthracosis; Byssinosis and Asbestosis
    • Exclusions from the Factory Act: The act does not apply to four specific sectors: the defense sector, mines, railways, and food joints or eateries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended spaces:

 

  • Floor space per person in a house: minimum 70 – 90 sq. ft.
  • Floor area per student in a class: > 10 sq. ft.
  • Space per worker in a factory (The Factory Act, 1948): >500 cu. ft.t

questions.text: PET scan is based on: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose metabolism

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans are primarily based on glucose metabolism. The radiopharmaceutical used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), which is an analog of glucose. This radiotracer is preferentially taken up by cells that have a high rate of glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells. The Warburg effect explains this phenomenon, where cancer cells consume glucose at much higher rates than normal cells, making them visible on PET scans due to the concentration of 18F-FDG.

 

Once 18F-FDG is inside the cell, it undergoes phosphorylation but does not proceed through the full glycolytic pathway, leading to its trapping within the cell. The emitted positrons from fluorine-18 collide with electrons in the body, producing gamma rays, which are detected by the PET scanner to create an image showing areas of high glucose metabolism.

 

Other 3 Options are incorrect, not the basis for PET scan.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

PET scans are based on glucose metabolism, utilizing 18F-FDG to detect areas of high metabolic activity, particularly in cancer cells.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cretinism

 

The child presents with symptoms that are highly characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, also known as cretinism. These symptoms include dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), and umbilical hernia. Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that arises from insufficient thyroid hormone production at birth. If untreated, it can lead to mental retardation and developmental delays. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. It does not typically present with macroglossia or umbilical hernia.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, Edward syndrome presents with severe intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and distinct facial features. While it can present with a range of symptoms, dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia are not typical features.

 

Option D. Galactosemia: This metabolic disorder is due to an inability to metabolize galactose properly. Symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, poor weight gain, and lethargy. It does not typically present with macroglossia, dry skin, or rough hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

questions.text: Which of the following IV anesthetics acts on an NMDA receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic that acts as an antagonist at the NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor. NMDA receptors are involved in the excitatory neurotransmission in the brain, particularly in the processes of synaptic plasticity and memory function. Ketamine inhibits these receptors, leading to a dissociative anesthesia characterized by analgesia, amnesia, and altered sensory perception without complete loss of consciousness. This unique mechanism of action makes ketamine distinct from other commonly used IV anesthetics.

 

Note - The inhalational agents that act on the NMDA receptor as antagonists are xenon and nitrous oxide

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol acts primarily as a GABA agonist, enhancing the activity of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA at the GABA-A receptor, leading to sedation and anesthesia. It does not act on NMDA receptors.

 

Option C. Thiopentone sodium: Thiopentone, a barbiturate, also works as a GABA agonist, similar to propofol. It does not affect NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that acts on the GABA-A receptor as well, increasing the inhibitory effects of GABA. Like propofol and thiopentone, it does not interact with NMDA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine is unique among IV anesthetics for its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist, leading to its characteristic dissociative anesthesia.

questions.text: A farmer had a thorn prick 3 weeks ago and presents with difficulty in opening jaw and muscle cramps. He is also having breathlessness. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tetanus

 

The patient presents with classic symptoms of tetanus, which include difficulty in opening the jaw (trismus), muscle cramps, and breathlessness. Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is often introduced through a wound such as a thorn prick. The symptoms of tetanus can develop days to weeks after the initial injury, as is the case here with the 3-week history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine poisoning can cause severe muscle spasms and cramps, but it typically presents acutely and is associated with a history of ingestion of the poison rather than an injury. Additionally, strychnine poisoning does not usually present with trismus (lockjaw).

 

Option C. Meningitis: Meningitis can cause symptoms like headache, fever, and neck stiffness, but it does not typically cause muscle cramps and difficulty in opening the jaw in the manner described.

 

Option D. Rabies: Rabies can cause neurological symptoms including hydrophobia and agitation, but it does not usually present with muscle cramps and trismus as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of tetanus should be considered in a patient with a history of a wound or injury followed by symptoms such as trismus, muscle cramps, and breathlessness, particularly if the onset of symptoms is delayed.

questions.text: A patient develops acute confusion and disorientation shortly after undergoing surgical intervention for a malignant tumor. Which of the following medications is typically the first-line treatment for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haloperidol

 

The patient is experiencing acute confusion and disorientation following surgery, which suggests the development of delirium. Delirium is a common postoperative complication, especially in older adults or those with significant medical conditions. The first-line treatment for delirium, particularly when it is accompanied by psychotic symptoms or severe agitation, is antipsychotic medication. Haloperidol is a traditional antipsychotic that is commonly used in this situation due to its efficacy in controlling these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, which is not typically used as a first-line treatment for delirium. It is more appropriate in the treatment of delirium tremens, which is a specific type of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal. In cases of delirium not related to alcohol withdrawal, lorazepam can actually worsen the confusion.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another antipsychotic that can be used to treat delirium, but it is not considered the first-line treatment as Haloperidol is more commonly preferred in acute cases.

 

Option D. Risperidone: Risperidone is also an antipsychotic that can be used in the management of delirium, but similar to Olanzapine, Haloperidol is generally preferred as the first-line option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haloperidol is the first-line treatment for delirium, especially when the patient exhibits significant agitation or psychotic symptoms following surgery.

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

An oil drop cataract is a specific type of cataract that is characteristically seen in patients with galactosemia. Galactosemia is an inherited disorder of galactose metabolism, where the body is unable to properly process galactose, a sugar found in milk. As a result of the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens of the eye, a cataract forms that resembles an oil droplet when viewed under certain lighting conditions. This cataract is often congenital or develops early in life, making it a common cause of pediatric cataracts.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. While it affects various organs, it does not typically cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Option C. Tay-Sachs disease: Tay-Sachs disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. It primarily affects the central nervous system and does not cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil drop cataracts are a hallmark feature of galactosemia, an inherited disorder affecting galactose metabolism, and they can present as congenital or developmental cataracts in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

 

The child presents with symptoms of mouth breathing and snoring, which are indicative of adenoid hypertrophy. The request to increase the TV volume suggests a hearing problem, likely due to conductive hearing loss caused by chronic adenoiditis with adenoid hypertrophy. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the Eustachian tube, leading to fluid accumulation in the middle ear, known as otitis media with effusion. This condition causes conductive hearing loss.

 

Adenoidectomy involves the surgical removal of the adenoids to alleviate the obstruction. Inserting a grommet (tympanostomy tube) allows for drainage of the middle ear fluid, improving hearing and preventing recurrent otitis media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy: While this addresses the adenoid hypertrophy, it does not address the fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The addition of a grommet is necessary for complete management.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone would not resolve the underlying issue of adenoid hypertrophy and chronic Eustachian tube obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach would not be suitable given the chronic nature of the symptoms and the associated hearing loss. Delaying treatment could lead to further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

questions.text: Most important enzyme in acute inflammation during respiratory burst is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

The respiratory burst is a crucial process in the immune response where neutrophils rapidly increase their oxygen consumption to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill invading pathogens. The key enzyme that initiates this process is NADPH oxidase (aka Respiratory burst oxidase enzyme). NADPH oxidase catalyzes the conversion of oxygen (O₂) into superoxide anions (O₂⁻), which are then further converted into more reactive species like hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and hypochlorous acid (HOCl-) via other enzymes like myeloperoxidase (MPO). These reactive species are potent antimicrobial agents, essential for destroying bacteria and fungi during acute inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MPO (Myeloperoxidase): While MPO is important in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide into hypochlorous acid (a powerful microbicidal agent), it acts downstream of NADPH oxidase. Thus, it is not the primary enzyme initiating the respiratory burst.

 

Option C. Defensin: Defensins are antimicrobial peptides that kill bacteria particularly against mycobacterium tuberculosis, by disrupting their cell membranes. They do not play a direct role in the respiratory burst or the generation of ROS.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, acting as an antioxidant to protect cells from oxidative damage. It does not contribute to the generation of ROS in the respiratory burst and is involved in mitigating the effects of ROS rather than promoting their formation.

 

Also, Catalase activity is used as a diagnostic tool to differentiate between types of bacteria. For example, the presence of catalase is used to distinguish catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus (staph) from catalase-negative organisms like Streptococcus (strep).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH oxidase is the most important enzyme in the process of respiratory burst during acute inflammation. It initiates the production of reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for the immune system's ability to kill pathogens.

questions.text: Anterior fontanelle closes at which age? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12-24 months

 

The anterior fontanelle is the largest of the fontanelles in an infant's skull, located at the junction of the frontal and parietal bones. It is diamond-shaped and is clinically significant as it remains open for a period after birth, allowing for the growth of the baby's brain and skull. The closure of the anterior fontanelle typically occurs between 12 to 24 months of age. This is an important developmental milestone and can vary slightly depending on individual growth patterns.

 

 

 

The provided images and discussion indicate that the anterior fontanelle is the last to close among the fontanelles. The posterior fontanelle closes around 3 months, the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle around 6 months, and the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelle around 12 months. Therefore, the anterior fontanelle, which closes between 12 to 24 months, is correctly identified by option A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 0-3 months: Incorrect. The posterior fontanelle typically closes during this period.

 

Option C. 10-12 months: Incorrect. The fontanelles closing around this age are the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelles.

 

Option D. 3-6 months: Incorrect. It corresponds to the closure time of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle, not the anterior fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 12 to 24 months of age, making this a key point for assessing normal infant development.

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trophic ulcer

 

The image shows an ulcer on the sole of the foot with a characteristic appearance. It is surrounded by a white area due to callosities, indicating chronic pressure. This description is typical of a trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer. These ulcers occur in areas of the body subjected to prolonged pressure, often in patients with peripheral neuropathy. The lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and subsequent ulceration, which is commonly seen in the weight-bearing areas such as the soles of the feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial ulcer: Arterial ulcers are typically located on the distal parts of the body such as the tips of toes and feet. They are often painful, with a "punched-out" appearance and a well-defined border. They usually have minimal exudate and occur due to inadequate blood supply.

 

Option B. Venous ulcer: Venous ulcers generally occur on the lower legs, particularly around the medial malleolus. They have irregular borders, are usually surrounded by hyperpigmentation, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are often exudative and less painful compared to arterial ulcers.

 

Option D. Diabetic ulcer: While diabetic ulcers can have a neuropathic component, they are a more complex condition with additional ischemic and infectious components. They are not exclusively located on pressure points and can appear anywhere on the foot. The distinguishing factor for trophic ulcers is their location on weight-bearing areas with surrounding callosities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophic (neuropathic) ulcers typically occur in weight-bearing areas, such as the soles of the feet, and are surrounded by callosities. They are primarily seen in patients with peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and ulceration. Recognizing this type of ulcer is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further complications.

questions.text: What will be the symptoms of a fracture at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anosmia

 

The marked area in the image corresponds to the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, which is located at the base of the skull. The cribriform plate is a thin, perforated structure through which the olfactory nerves (Cranial Nerve I) pass from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

If this area is fractured, it can lead to damage to the olfactory nerves, resulting in anosmia, which is the loss of the sense of smell. Anosmia is a common symptom associated with fractures of the cribriform plate, as the olfactory nerves are particularly vulnerable in this region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoacusis: Hypoacusis refers to reduced hearing ability and is typically associated with damage to the auditory structures or the auditory nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII). This symptom is not related to fractures of the cribriform plate.

 

Option B. Visual loss: Visual loss would occur due to damage to the optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) or structures of the eye, not the cribriform plate. The optic nerve passes through the optic canal, not the cribriform plate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone can lead to anosmia due to damage to the olfactory nerves. This area is crucial for the sense of smell.

questions.text: The chronic alcoholic patient had a history of strenuous exercise but forgot to take his meal, later had alcohol in a party, and presented with hypoglycemia. Which of the following processes is inhibited by alcohol? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gluconeogenesis

 

Alcohol metabolism involves the conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde and then to acetic acid. Both steps generate NADH through the actions of alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase, respectively. The excessive production of NADH in the liver causes a shift in the metabolic equilibrium.

 

Increased levels of NADH favor the conversion of pyruvate to lactate (lactic acidosis) and oxaloacetate to malate. Since pyruvate and oxaloacetate are key substrates for gluconeogenesis (the process of generating glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), their depletion inhibits gluconeogenesis. This metabolic inhibition leads to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted, as in the case of the patient who had undergone strenuous exercise and had not eaten.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogenolysis: This process, which involves the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, is not directly inhibited by alcohol. However, once glycogen stores are depleted, the body relies on gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels, which is impaired by alcohol.

 

Option B. HMP shunt: The Hexose Monophosphate shunt (also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway) is involved in generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate but is not directly affected by alcohol metabolism.

 

Option D. Ketone bodies synthesis: While chronic alcohol consumption can lead to ketoacidosis, the synthesis of ketone bodies is not inhibited by alcohol. Instead, alcohol can lead to a buildup of acetyl-CoA, which can actually promote ketogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH, which inhibits gluconeogenesis by depleting pyruvate and oxaloacetate, leading to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Resection and anastomosis

 

The image shows a suture line between two ends of the bowel, indicating that the ends of the bowel are being joined. This is typically done after a surgical procedure where a segment of the bowel has been removed, necessitating the rejoining of the remaining bowel ends. This procedure is known as resection and anastomosis. The visual cues of the bowel ends being sutured together are indicative of this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary closure of perforation: This would involve suturing a perforation directly without removing a segment of the bowel, which is not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Ileostomy: This procedure involves creating an opening (stoma) on the surface of the skin, which is not depicted in the provided image. The image shows internal suturing, not an external stoma.

 

Option D. Resection alone: This would mean removing a section of the bowel without rejoining the ends, which is not shown in the image. The image clearly depicts the bowel ends being sutured together, indicating an anastomosis following resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In surgical procedures involving the bowel, when two bowel ends are being sutured together, the procedure is referred to as resection and anastomosis.

choices.text: First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: A patient presented with red, tender, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. Which of the following is more appropriately done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

 

The patient presents with a red, tender, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. The term "pulsatile" suggests that the swelling has a vascular origin, likely an aneurysm or other vascular abnormality. The primary goal in managing such a swelling is to correctly identify its nature, which necessitates imaging.

 

Angiography is an imaging modality that visualizes blood vessels, helping to confirm whether the swelling is vascular, such as an aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm. This step is critical because if the swelling is indeed vascular, inappropriate interventions like incision and drainage could lead to severe complications, including hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:
