Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This is inflammation of the front part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and typically causes pain, redness, and photophobia, but not a curtain-like visual symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

3 types of RD: Rhegmatogenous, Tractional and Exudative Retinal Detachment

 

1.   Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment:

  • Most common form, occurring when a tear or hole in the retina allows fluid to enter and accumulate under the retina, separating it from the underlying tissues.
  • Classical symptoms include visual flashes and floaters, which are due to the movement of the detached retina.
  • A "curtain falling" sign, where a section of the visual field appears to be shaded, is characteristic of this type.

 

2.  Tractional Retinal Detachment:

  • Occurs when fibrous or fibrovascular tissue, often resulting from proliferative diabetic retinopathy or other conditions, exerts traction on the retina, pulling it away from its underlying support tissue.

 

3.  Exudative Retinal Detachment:

  • Also known as serous retinal detachment, this type occurs without tears or breaks in the retina.
  • Fluid accumulates under the retina due to inflammation, injury, or vascular abnormalities causing leakage.

questions.text: Which of the following component is absent in the smooth muscle? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Troponin

 

Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not contain troponin. In smooth muscle cells, actin and myosin are present and are essential for muscle contraction. Tropomyosin is also present in smooth muscle, though its role differs from that in skeletal muscle. While in skeletal muscle, tropomyosin blocks the myosin binding sites on actin filaments, its function in smooth muscle is still not completely understood but is thought to aid in muscle contraction. Troponin, however, is absent in smooth muscle.

 

In skeletal muscle, troponin binds to calcium ions during muscle contraction, facilitating the interaction between actin and myosin.

 

Smooth muscle uses calmodulin to bind calcium instead of troponin, enabling muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Actin: Actin is present in smooth muscle and plays a crucial role in the contraction process by interacting with myosin.

 

Option B. Myosin: Myosin is also present in smooth muscle and is essential for contraction as it interacts with actin.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is present in smooth muscle. Although its exact role differs from that in skeletal muscle, it is involved in the contraction mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Troponin is absent in smooth muscle; instead, calcium binds to calmodulin to facilitate muscle contraction.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great cardiac vein

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the great cardiac vein. The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD). This vein collects blood from the anterior surfaces of both ventricles and drains into the coronary sinus.

 

The great cardiac vein is the largest of the veins draining the heart muscle (myocardium), and it is crucial in returning deoxygenated blood from the myocardium to the coronary sinus and eventually into the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cardiac vein: These veins drain directly into the right atrium and do not run in the anterior interventricular sulcus. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Middle cardiac vein: This vein runs in the posterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the posterior interventricular artery. It is not located in the anterior interventricular sulcus, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Small cardiac vein: This vein is located on the right side of the heart and accompanies the right coronary artery. It is not associated with the anterior interventricular sulcus, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular sulcus with the anterior interventricular artery and is crucial for draining blood from the anterior aspects of the heart.

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the carotid and aortic bodies that detect changes in blood oxygen levels. These receptors play a critical role in the respiratory control by responding to hypoxia (low oxygen levels). The oxygen-sensitive channels in these receptors are specifically sensitive to potassium ions (K+). When oxygen levels drop, these potassium channels close, which leads to a series of events: membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and ultimately, the release of neurotransmitters like ATP. This process triggers signals that increase respiratory activity to raise blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Sodium channels are important in many physiological processes, but they are not specifically sensitive to oxygen levels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option C. HCO3-: Bicarbonate ions are involved in acid-base balance and CO2 transport but are not directly involved in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions play roles in various cellular processes, including maintaining osmotic balance, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. These spots are part of a condition called xerophthalmia, which is dryness of the eye due to vitamin A deficiency. Bitot spots represent a more advanced stage of xerophthalmia, classified as stage X1B in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposition line seen in front of a pterygium. It is not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option B. Pinguecula: This is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the corneal limbus. It's caused by elastotic degeneration due to prolonged UV exposure, not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva extending onto the cornea. Like pinguecula, it's associated with UV exposure and not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. His urine analysis shows RBC casts without any significant findings. The likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA vasculitis

 

The clinical scenario described in the question is highly suggestive of IgA vasculitis, which was previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). This condition is characterized by the involvement of multiple organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, joints, skin, and kidneys. The hallmark features of IgA vasculitis include:

 

  1. Gastrointestinal Involvement: Patients often present with abdominal pain, which may be due to vasculitis of the mesenteric vessels. In severe cases, it can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
  2. Joint Involvement: Arthralgia or arthritis is common, particularly affecting the knees and ankles.
  3. Skin Involvement: The presence of palpable purpura, typically on the lower extremities, is a key clinical feature. This is a type of non-thrombocytopenic purpura, indicating that the purpura is not due to low platelet counts.
  4. Renal Involvement: The presence of RBC casts in the urine analysis indicates glomerulonephritis, which is a common renal manifestation of IgA vasculitis.

 

IgA vasculitis is primarily an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis. The deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in the small vessels leads to the inflammation and damage seen in the affected organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behcet disease: This condition is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, as well as uveitis. It does not typically present with the combination of symptoms described in this case, particularly the specific renal involvement with RBC casts.

 

Option B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's): This is a form of vasculitis that typically involves the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys, but it does not present with palpable purpura or the same pattern of multi-organ involvement seen in IgA vasculitis.

 

Option D. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): SLE can present with a wide variety of symptoms due to its multi-system involvement. However, the specific combination of abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and RBC casts is more characteristic of IgA vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA vasculitis, previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, is characterized by abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and renal involvement with RBC casts. It is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.

questions.text: What is the compression to ventilation ratio in an adult cardiac arrest patient in the presence of more than one rescuer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult patients experiencing cardiac arrest, the recommended compression to ventilation ratio during CPR is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers present. This ratio ensures that adequate chest compressions are delivered to maintain blood circulation while allowing time for sufficient ventilation to oxygenate the blood. The priority in adult CPR is effective chest compressions, which is why the ratio is set to 30 compressions for every 2 ventilations.

 

This ratio remains constant irrespective of whether there is one rescuer or more than one, ensuring consistency and simplicity during the resuscitation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For adult CPR, regardless of the number of rescuers, the compression to ventilation ratio should always be 30:2 to ensure effective circulation and oxygenation during cardiac arrest.

 

Additionally, For children with one rescuer, the ratio is 30 compressions to 2 ventilations (30:2); with two rescuers, the ratio is 15 compressions to 2 ventilations (15:2). For neonates, the ratio is 3 compressions to 1 ventilation (3:1).

choices.text: Medial cutaneous nerve of arm
Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm

questions.text: A patient experiences chest pain radiating to the arm. Which nerve can be responsible for the radiating pain? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercostobrachial nerve

 

The intercostobrachial nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the skin of the upper medial aspect of the arm and also partially the chest wall. It is a branch of the second intercostal nerve (T2) and often gets involved in referred pain during conditions like myocardial infarction. The radiating pain from the chest to the arm, particularly in the case of heart attacks, is due to the involvement of the intercostobrachial nerve. This nerve shares dermatomes with the T1-T2 spinal segments, which also receive cardiac sensory fibers, leading to the referred pain in the arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm and provides sensory innervation to the lateral forearm, not typically associated with chest pain radiating to the arm.

 

Option C. Medial cutaneous nerve of arm: This nerve supplies the skin on the medial side of the arm but does not typically carry pain from the chest. It's not usually involved in referred cardiac pain.

 

Option D. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm: This nerve supplies the skin on the medial side of the forearm and is also not typically involved in radiating chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intercostobrachial nerve, originating from T2, is responsible for the sensation in the upper medial arm and can be involved in referred pain from the chest, such as during a myocardial infarction. This nerve is key in understanding the dermatome distribution related to cardiac pain.

choices.text: Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space
CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, and hypotension. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side and a hyper-resonant note was felt on percussion. X-ray is shown. What will be your immediate management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

 

The clinical presentation of subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, hypotension, absent air entry, and hyper-resonant note on percussion strongly suggests a tension pneumothorax. This condition is confirmed by the X-ray, which shows a dark lung field on the right side due to air in the pleural space, a collapsed lung border, and a shift of the mediastinum and trachea to the left side.

 

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to relieve the pressure in the pleural space. The recommended immediate management is needle thoracostomy, which involves the insertion of a wide-bore needle into the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line to rapidly decompress the pleural space, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent tracheostomy: This is not the immediate management for tension pneumothorax. Tracheostomy is typically performed to secure the airway in cases of upper airway obstruction.

 

Option C. IV fluids: While IV fluids may be administered to manage hypotension, they do not address the underlying cause of tension pneumothorax and are not the immediate life-saving intervention required.

 

Option D. CT scan of the chest: Imaging studies like a CT scan are not performed immediately in cases of tension pneumothorax due to the urgent need for decompression to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management for tension pneumothorax is needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby was presented with severe hepatomegaly, jaundice, and cataract in both eyes. The child appeared lethargic and hypotonic. Identify the enzyme involved? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gal-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The condition described in the question is classic galactosemia, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. This enzyme is crucial for the proper metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in the liver, leading to the symptoms described, including hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), jaundice, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia. The accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes inorganic phosphate, which impairs glycogen breakdown and leads to hypoglycemia.

 

In classic galactosemia, the symptoms typically appear within the first few weeks of life, especially when the infant is breastfed (since breast milk contains lactose, which is broken down into glucose and galactose). The presence of cataracts is due to the accumulation of galactitol, a byproduct of galactose metabolism that forms in the lens of the eye.

 

 

Galactose Metabolism

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactokinase: Deficiency in galactokinase leads to a milder form of galactosemia, characterized primarily by the formation of cataracts due to galactitol accumulation. However, it does not cause severe symptoms like hepatomegaly, jaundice, or lethargy, making it an incorrect answer.

 

Option C. Hepatic Glucose 6 Phosphatase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes von Gierke disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), which presents with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia but does not cause cataracts. The lack of cataract formation and the specific features of von Gierke disease (such as lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia) rule out this option.

 

Option D. Fructokinase: Deficiency in fructokinase causes essential fructosuria, which is a benign condition with no symptoms. Hereditary fructose intolerance, caused by aldolase B deficiency, can cause symptoms like hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia but typically presents after the introduction of fructose into the diet, and does not cause cataracts. Thus, fructokinase deficiency is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency in Gal-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to severe symptoms such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, particularly in breastfed infants.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a documented 20-year history of alcohol abuse, consuming approximately 500 ml of alcohol daily, presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of disorientation, sensation of insects crawling on the skin, and severe agitation. Given this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium


The patient’s symptoms of disorientation, hallucinations (e.g., sensation of insects crawling on the skin), and severe agitation, particularly in the context of a long history of heavy alcohol use, strongly suggest delirium tremens (DT), which is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal delirium. Although the history does not explicitly mention cessation of alcohol, these symptoms are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal delirium, which typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. DT is associated with a disturbance in consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, and often visual hallucinations, but can include auditory or tactile hallucinations as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute alcohol intoxication: This condition is usually characterized by slurred speech, unsteady gait, and impaired judgment. However, it does not typically present with the degree of disorientation, agitation, or hallucinations described in this case.

 

Option C. Alcohol-induced persisting dementia: This condition results from long-term alcohol abuse, leading to permanent cognitive impairment, but it develops gradually over time and does not present acutely with hallucinations and severe agitation.

 

Option D. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: This syndrome is associated with a thiamine deficiency and presents with the classic triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. The symptoms in the question do not match this profile, ruling it out.

 

Educational Objective:


Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that presents with disorientation, hallucinations, and agitation, typically occurring 48-72 hours after the last drink

questions.text: The most common cancer found among the female population in India is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer affecting the female population.

 

It ranks highest in terms of incidence, prevalence, and mortality among cancers in women.

 

Breast cancer has overtaken cervical cancer, which used to be the leading cause of cancer-related morbidity among Indian women. This shift reflects changes in lifestyle, reproductive patterns, and awareness.

 

Statistically, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among Indian women, and its incidence continues to rise, making it a significant public health concern. Additionally, breast cancer is also the most common cancer when considering the total population (both male and female) combined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral and lip cancer: While oral and lip cancers are common in India, particularly due to tobacco use, they are more prevalent in males and do not surpass breast cancer in females in terms of incidence.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Cervical cancer was previously the most common cancer among women in India. However, breast cancer has now overtaken it in terms of both incidence and mortality.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: Lung cancer, while common, is more prevalent in males. It is not the most common cancer among females in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among the female population in India, leading in incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates. Followed by cervico-uterine cancer, ovarian cancer, lip and oral cavity cancer, and colorectal cancer, respectively.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation
Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

 

The image shows a reducible swelling on the patient's back, which strongly suggests a hernia. Hernias are defined as protrusions of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening. When a hernia is reducible, it means that the protruded organ or tissue can be pushed back into its original place.

 

The standard treatment for a reducible hernia is surgical repair. This often involves reducing the hernia and reinforcing the weakened area with a mesh to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly important to avoid complications such as strangulation or incarceration of the herniated contents, which can become medical emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage: This procedure is typically used for abscesses or other collections of pus, not for hernias. Hernias do not require drainage as there is no infection involved.

 

Option B. Reduce the swelling and do the observation: While reducing the swelling might temporarily alleviate symptoms, observation alone is not a definitive treatment for a hernia. Without surgical repair, the hernia is likely to recur and may lead to complications.

 

Option D. Observation alone: This option is not advisable for hernias as it does not address the underlying defect in the abdominal wall or the risk of potential complications. Hernias generally require surgical intervention to prevent recurrence and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: Lagophthalmos is caused by defect in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 7th cranial nerve

 

Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eye completely. This condition is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve). The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is responsible for closing the eyelid. When this nerve is damaged or dysfunctional, it leads to weakness or paralysis of the orbicularis oculi, resulting in incomplete eyelid closure.

 

 

Note - It's important to distinguish between "lagophthalmos" (inability to close the eye) and "lid lag" (where the eyelid doesn't follow the eyeball's movement properly), as both involve "lag" but refer to different phenomena and are caused by different underlying issues.

 

Lid Lag occurs when the eyelid fails to follow the downward movement of the eyeball when shifting from an upward gaze to a straight or downward gaze. This condition is noticeable in thyroid eye disease and is associated with von Graefe's sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for raising the upper eyelid. A defect in this nerve would cause ptosis (drooping eyelid) rather than lagophthalmos.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve: The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is involved in eye movement. It is not directly related to eyelid function.

 

Option C. 6th cranial nerve: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for lateral eye movement. It does not control eyelid function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle responsible for eyelid closure

questions.text: The corrected refractory error is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presbyopia

 

The "corrected" refractory error, which implies the condition after it has been corrected with appropriate lenses. Presbyopia is unique among the options as it's not a refractive error in the traditional sense, but an age-related condition affecting near vision. When corrected with reading glasses or multifocal lenses, presbyopia allows for clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively "correcting" the inability to focus on near objects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia: This is a refractive error where distant objects appear blurry. It's corrected with concave (minus) lenses, not the correction itself.

 

Option B. Hypermetropia (Hyperopia):  This condition causes difficulty focusing on near objects and is corrected with convex (plus) lenses, but it's not the corrected state.

 

Option D. Astigmatism:  This is an imperfection in the curvature of the eye's cornea or lens, corrected with cylindrical lenses, but again, it's not the corrected state itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presbyopia is unique among refractive conditions as its correction (typically with reading glasses) results in clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively achieving a "corrected" state for both near and far vision

questions.text: Identify the hormone secreted by the zone of adrenal cortex shown by the arrow: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Androgens

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for secreting different types of hormones. The zones are as follows:

 

  1. Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex. It secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which are crucial for regulating sodium and potassium balance and, consequently, blood pressure.
  2. Zona Fasciculata: This is the middle layer of the adrenal cortex. It secretes glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol, which are involved in the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, as well as in the body's response to stress.
  3. Zona Reticularis: This is the innermost layer of the adrenal cortex. It secretes androgens, such as dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), which are precursors to sex steroids.

 

In the provided image, the arrow points to the bottom layer of the adrenal cortex, which is the zona reticularis. Therefore, the hormone secreted by this zone is androgens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucocorticoid: These hormones are secreted by the zona fasciculata, the middle layer of the adrenal cortex, not by the zona reticularis.

 

Option B. Mineralocorticoid: These hormones are secreted by the zona glomerulosa, the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex, not by the zona reticularis.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is secreted by the adrenal medulla, not by the adrenal cortex. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines like adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine), which are involved in the body's fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenal Cortex

  • Zona glomerulosa secretes Mineralocorticoids
  • Zona fasciculata secretes Glucocorticoid
  • Zona reticularis secretes Androgens

 

Adrenal Gland

  • Adrenal medulla secretes Epinephrine and Norepinephrine

questions.text: What is the neoadjuvant therapy used for GIST? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imatinib

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are most commonly associated with mutations in the KIT gene or PDGFRA gene. Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is used as neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs to shrink the tumor before surgery. This is particularly effective in GISTs with KIT mutations and some PDGFRA mutations.

 

However, not all GISTs respond to imatinib. For instance, GISTs with the PDGFRA D842V mutation or those classified as "wild-type" (lacking KIT or PDGFRA mutations) do not respond well to imatinib. In such cases, surgery is considered the primary treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used in various inflammatory and autoimmune conditions but not typically used for GISTs.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent used in certain cancers and autoimmune conditions, but it is not used for GISTs.

 

Option D. Indomethacin:  Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation but has no role in the treatment of GISTs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imatinib is the preferred neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs with KIT or certain PDGFRA mutations to reduce tumor size before surgery. It is not effective for all GISTs, particularly those with specific mutations such as PDGFRA D842V or "wild-type" GISTs.

questions.text: Methotrexate acts by inhibiting: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune system suppressant. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. This enzyme is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a form of folic acid that is required for the synthesis of thymidylate, purines, and the amino acid methionine.

 

By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate effectively depletes the cell’s supply of tetrahydrofolate, which in turn inhibits DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis. This inhibition is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cells, which is why methotrexate is used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymidylate synthetase: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP) from deoxyuridylate (dUMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis. This enzyme is inhibited by 5-Fluorouracil, not methotrexate.

 

Option B. DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase is an enzyme responsible for forming new copies of DNA, but methotrexate does not directly inhibit this enzyme. Inhibition of DNA polymerase would prevent DNA replication, but methotrexate acts upstream in the folate pathway.

 

Option C. RNA Polymerase: RNA polymerase is responsible for synthesizing RNA from a DNA template. Methotrexate does not inhibit RNA polymerase; instead, it inhibits the production of necessary components for DNA and RNA synthesis indirectly by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, thereby preventing the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does NOT involve intracellular accumulation of cholesterol and cholesterol esters? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abetalipoproteinemia

 

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP), leading to defective chylomicron formation and VLDL, IDL LDL . Chylomicrons are necessary for transporting dietary fats and fat-soluble vitamins. As a result, affected individuals present with steatorrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, and neurological manifestations. There is a notable absence of intracellular cholesterol accumulation, unlike the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tendon Xanthomas: Nodules or plaques that form on tendons due to cholesterol and cholesterol ester accumulation. Common in familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option C. Strawberry Gallbladder: Also known as cholesterolosis, it involves cholesterol accumulation in the gallbladder mucosa, giving it a strawberry-like appearance.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick Disease: A lysosomal storage disorder caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency, leading to cholesterol and lipid buildup in organs such as the liver and spleen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abetalipoproteinemia is a condition where intracellular cholesterol does not accumulate, differentiating it from disorders like tendon xanthomas, strawberry gallbladder, and Niemann-Pick disease, which involve cholesterol buildup.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with anemia. What is the most common cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia across all age groups, including older adults. It occurs when the body's iron stores are depleted, leading to reduced production of hemoglobin and red blood cells. This condition is especially common in older adults due to factors such as poor dietary intake, gastrointestinal bleeding, and malabsorption.

 

In elderly patients, it is crucial to rule out underlying causes of iron deficiency anemia, particularly gastrointestinal malignancies such as colorectal cancer. For postmenopausal women and elderly men presenting with anemia, investigations such as colonoscopy or fecal occult blood tests are important to identify or exclude potential sources of chronic blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is common in patients with chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies, but it is not the most common cause of anemia in the general elderly population.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia:  A rare condition characterized by pancytopenia and bone marrow failure. It is not a common cause of anemia in the elderly.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome:  A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells, more common in older adults, but not as prevalent as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia, especially in elderly patients, and requires thorough evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions such as gastrointestinal malignancies.

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder dystocia

 

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where, after the delivery of the fetal head, the shoulders fail to deliver within a typical interval. The definition of shoulder dystocia includes a delivery interval between the head and the shoulders exceeding one minute or requiring specific maneuvers to release the shoulders. This condition occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts behind the maternal pubic symphysis or, less commonly, the posterior shoulder impacts the sacral promontory.

 

In this scenario, the head was delivered, but the shoulders got stuck, fitting the clinical definition of shoulder dystocia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): This is incorrect as CPD refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis, preventing the fetal head from entering or passing through the birth canal. It does not specifically describe the situation where the shoulders get stuck after the head is delivered.

 

Option C. Occipito posterior: This option is incorrect because it refers to the fetal head being positioned posteriorly in the pelvis, which can cause prolonged labor but does not directly result in shoulder dystocia. In occipito posterior positions, the delivery complication is typically a "face to pubis" delivery, not shoulder entrapment.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: This is incorrect as it describes a fetal position where the fetus lies horizontally in the uterus, which leads to complications like neglected shoulder with hand prolapse if the membranes rupture. The presentation is the shoulder, not the head, which means it does not fit the scenario where the head is delivered but the shoulders are stuck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.

questions.text: A couple presents to the OPD with their 4-year-old child who has self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Identify the condition and enzyme involved in it: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HGPRT deficiency

 

The child’s symptoms of self-mutilating behavior and poor growth are characteristic of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. This is a rare inherited disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme is crucial in the purine salvage pathway, where it recycles purines into nucleotides rather than letting them degrade into uric acid.

 

When HGPRT is deficient, purines like hypoxanthine and guanine accumulate and are subsequently converted to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia and gout. The neurological manifestations, including self-mutilation and mental retardation, arise due to the deficiency in purine recycling, which is critical for proper brain function.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Xanthine oxidase is inhibited by allopurinol
  • The enzyme for salvage pathway is HGPRT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogentisic Acid Oxidase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes Alkaptonuria, not Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. Alkaptonuria is characterized by dark urine, ochronosis, and arthritis, not self-mutilation or poor growth.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by intellectual disability and a musty body odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine, but not self-mutilation or gout.

 

Option D. Benzoyl Acidase: This is not a relevant enzyme in this context, and its mention is incorrect or misleading.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is caused by a complete deficiency of HGPRT, leading to self-mutilation, poor growth, hyperuricemia, and gout.

questions.text: An adult male presented to the OPD with a swelling in the scrotum which was painful. The patient was having fever as well. The swelling was in relation to the tunica vaginalis and fluid collection was present. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocele

 

The patient presents with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is noted to be in relation to the tunica vaginalis with fluid collection, which points towards a secondary hydrocele due to an underlying condition.

 

The combination of painful scrotal swelling and fever is indicative of an inflammatory or infectious process, most commonly acute epididymo-orchitis. This condition is inflammation of the epididymis and testicle, often caused by bacterial infection. The presence of fluid around the testicle, known as a hydrocele, is a secondary response to the inflammation.

 

A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. Secondary hydroceles can develop in response to infections, injuries, or inflammatory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicocele: This is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum (the pampiniform plexus). It is typically not associated with fever or acute pain and does not involve fluid collection related to the tunica vaginalis.

 

Option C. Cystocele: This condition involves the bladder bulging into the vaginal space and is unrelated to scrotal swelling.

 

Option D. Torsion testis: Testicular torsion involves the twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to severe pain and swelling. While torsion can occur in adults, it is more common in adolescents. It usually does not present with fever unless secondary infection occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful scrotal swelling with fever and fluid collection in an adult male, particularly in relation to the tunica vaginalis, suggests a diagnosis of secondary hydrocele due to epididymo-orchitis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood that has not been processed by the liver into its conjugated form. Gilbert syndrome is a common genetic disorder that causes mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition results from reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: (Mnemonic: DR BHATIA)

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This condition causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the liver's ability to secrete conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts, leading to its buildup in the liver.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome also leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign condition that results from a defect in the hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This condition also results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a serious liver disease in infants where the bile ducts become inflamed and blocked, preventing bile from draining from the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymph node enlargement whose tissue biopsy image is provided here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The biopsy image provided shows the characteristic features of a granulomatous inflammation with the presence of Langhans giant cells. Langhans giant cells are multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, and they are commonly seen in granulomas associated with tuberculosis. These cells have a distinctive arrangement of nuclei in a horseshoe or ring shape, which is a hallmark of tubercular granulomas.

 

In this clinical scenario, the patient presents with fever and lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy), which, along with the biopsy findings, strongly suggests a diagnosis of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis is a common cause of granulomatous inflammation, particularly in regions where the disease is endemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: This is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, which have a distinctive "owl's eye" appearance. These cells are not present in the biopsy image provided.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis also causes granulomatous inflammation but typically does not show caseation necrosis or Langhans giant cells. Non-caseating granulomas are more typical of sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Secondaries: This refers to metastatic cancer involving the lymph nodes. The biopsy image does not show the characteristic features of metastatic cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langhans giant cells, with their horseshoe-shaped nuclei, are a characteristic finding in granulomas associated with tuberculosis, making this the most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Calculate the mid parental height of a male patient with father height 183 cm and mother height 175 cm? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 185.5

 

The mid-parental height (MPH) is a method used to estimate the potential adult height of a child based on the heights of the parents.

 

Formula:

 

Using the given heights:

 

  • Father's height = 183 cm
  • Mother's height = 175 cm
  • MPH = [(183+175)/2] + 6.5 = 185.5

 

Therefore, the mid-parental height is 185.5 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To calculate the mid-parental height for a male child, use the formula:

 

(Father’s height+Mother’s height)/2+6.5 cm.

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas found on the iris and are a hallmark of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are usually benign and do not affect vision. However, their presence is a key diagnostic criterion for NF1. Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas), cafe-au-lait macules (light brown skin spots), and skin fold freckling. Another significant feature is plexiform neurofibroma, which can present congenitally.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This is incorrect. Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by different skin lesions such as hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, and Shagreen patches. Lisch nodules are not associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Leprosy: This is incorrect. Leprosy (Hansen's disease) primarily affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, but it does not involve the development of Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: This is incorrect. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, often affecting the lungs and lymph nodes, but not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are an important diagnostic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A patient has come to the clinic. Identify the movement being examined in the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction

 

The image provided depicts a clinical examination known as the Trendelenburg test. This test is used to assess the strength and function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. These muscles, innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, stabilize the pelvis during walking by keeping the pelvis level when one leg is lifted off the ground.

 

 

In a normal Trendelenburg test, when the patient stands on one leg, the gluteus medius and minimus on the standing leg contract to elevate the pelvis on the opposite side, maintaining balance. If the superior gluteal nerve is damaged or the gluteus medius and minimus muscles are weak or paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction: Adduction refers to the movement of a limb toward the midline of the body. This is not the movement being assessed in the Trendelenburg test.

 

Option B. Extension: Extension is the straightening movement that increases the angle between body parts, such as straightening the leg at the hip joint. The Trendelenburg test does not assess extension.

 

Option C. Flexion: Flexion refers to bending a joint, decreasing the angle between body parts. The Trendelenburg test is not assessing flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Trendelenburg test assesses the function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. A positive Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of these muscles, often due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: What concentration of fluoride is typically associated with causing crippling fluorosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 10 mg/L.

 

Fluoride is an element that, in appropriate concentrations, can prevent dental caries, but excessive intake can lead to various forms of fluorosis. The concentration of fluoride in drinking water (0.5-0.8 ppm or mg/L) is a key determinant of its effects on health.

 

  • Dental fluorosis typically occurs when the fluoride concentration exceeds 1.5 mg/L.
  • Skeletal fluorosis may develop when the concentration of fluoride in drinking water is between 3 to 6 mg/L.
  • Crippling fluorosis, the most severe form of fluorosis, occurs when the fluoride concentration exceeds 10 mg/L. At this level, the fluoride can cause severe joint pain, bone deformities, and can result in significant disability.

 

Thus, a fluoride concentration of greater than 10 mg/L is associated with the development of crippling fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Fluorine is a double edged sword’: Inadequate intake is associated with ‘dental caries’ whereas excess intake with ‘dental and skeletal fluorosis’

 

Crippling fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 10 mg/L, leading to severe and disabling conditions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with progressive abdominal distension and episodes of vague abdominal discomfort over the past few months. On examination, there is evidence of increased abdominal girth with diffuse tenderness. Imaging studies reveal copious mucinous deposits throughout the peritoneal cavity consistent with pseudomyxoma peritonei. What is the most common primary source of this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Appendiceal mucinous neoplasm

 

The most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is an appendiceal mucinous neoplasm, particularly a low-grade appendiceal mucinous tumor. When the tumor ruptures, it releases mucin-secreting epithelial cells into the peritoneal cavity, resulting in the accumulation of mucinous material. This process leads to the classic "jelly belly" appearance and persistent intra-abdominal deposits of gelatinous mucinous material.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary: Mucinous cystadenomas can also cause pseudomyxoma peritonei, but the most common cause remains an appendiceal neoplasm.

 

Option B. Teratoma: Teratomas do not typically lead to pseudomyxoma peritonei. These tumors contain multiple tissue types and are often localized.

 

Option D. Gastric adenocarcinoma: Gastric adenocarcinoma can cause peritoneal metastasis but does not typically result in pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is an appendiceal mucinous neoplasm. PMP is characterized by the accumulation of mucin-producing tumor cells within the peritoneal cavity, resulting in the formation of "jelly belly."

questions.text: Anticancer drug that can result in hand and foot syndrome is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and both of these drugs are known to cause hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). This condition is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It occurs due to the leakage of the drug from capillaries in these areas, leading to skin toxicity. Hand-foot syndrome is a well-documented adverse effect of capecitabine, making it the correct answer in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is associated with a different side effect profile, most notably hemorrhagic cystitis, which can be prevented by the administration of mesna.

 

Option B. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and can also result in flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: Paclitaxel is an anticancer drug that primarily causes peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine & 5FU can cause hand-foot syndrome, which is an important side effect to monitor in patients receiving this treatment.

questions.text: Sludder’s neuralgia is due to compression of anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, also known as anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, occurs due to the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve. This nerve provides sensory innervation to parts of the nasal cavity and the anterior part of the cranial cavity. A septal spur, which is a sharp bony projection from the nasal septum, can impinge on the middle turbinate where the anterior ethmoidal nerve traverses. This compression can cause pain and headache in the regions supplied by the nerve, commonly leading to facial pain and nasal discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior turbinate: While the superior turbinate is located higher in the nasal cavity, it is not typically involved in the compression causing Sludder’s neuralgia. The anterior ethmoidal nerve runs closer to the middle turbinate.

 

Option B. Inferior turbinate: The inferior turbinate is situated lower in the nasal cavity and does not typically come into contact with the septal spur affecting the anterior ethmoidal nerve. Therefore, it is not involved in Sludder’s neuralgia.

 

Option D. Supreme turbinate: The supreme turbinate is an anatomical variant that some individuals have above the superior turbinate. This is not commonly implicated in conditions involving the anterior ethmoidal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, or anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, is caused by the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate. This condition results in facial pain and headache due to nerve irritation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoes an upper gastrointestinal motility study due to unexplained abdominal pain and bloating that worsens during fasting. The motility recording, shown in the image below, displays distinct phases of activity. Which of the following types of gastrointestinal motility is most likely represented in this study? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Migrating motor complex (MMC)

 

The Migrating Motor Complex (MMC) is a fasting-related motility pattern that clears the gastrointestinal tract between meals. It has three phases: a resting phase (Phase I), irregular contractions (Phase II), and strong, regular contractions (Phase III). Occurring every 90–120 minutes, the MMC helps move residual food and secretions through the intestines, starting in the stomach and preventing bacterial overgrowth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peristalsis: Refers to the coordinated contractions that move food through the digestive tract after meals, not during fasting. It involves rhythmic contractions behind the food bolus and relaxation ahead of it, pushing the contents forward.

 

Option B. Segmentation and mixing: These movements mix intestinal contents and aid in absorption. They occur after eating, involving localized contractions that mix food with digestive juices.

 

Option D. Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER): Refers to the slow, wave-like electrical activity generated by pacemaker cells (interstitial cells of Cajal) that regulate muscle contractions in the gut. This is more continuous and not directly associated with the distinct MMC phases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The migrating motor complex (MMC) is a fasting-related motility pattern that ensures the gastrointestinal tract is cleared between meals, preventing bacterial overgrowth and preparing the gut for digestion of the next meal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with chest pain and an ECG was taken. What will be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior MI

 

The ECG shows ST elevations primarily in leads V1, V2, V3, and V4. These elevations are also seen to some extent in V5 and aVL, with reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. These findings are characteristic of an anterior myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior MI: This would present with ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. These changes are not observed in the provided ECG.

 

Option C. Lateral MI: This type of MI would show ST elevations primarily in leads I, aVL, and possibly V5 and V6, but not in leads V1 to V4.

 

Option D. Posterior MI: The diagnosis of a posterior MI is typically confirmed by obtaining posterior leads (V7, V8, and V9) to demonstrate ST elevations. Alternatively, it can be inferred from characteristic ST depressions in leads V1 and V2, often with a tall R wave and upright T wave, which are not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior MI is characterized by ST elevations in leads V1 to V4, with possible involvement of V5 and AVL, and reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF.

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever. The biopsy has revealed granulomatous necrotizing inflammation. Which of the following is the likely finding with this presentation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels

 

The patient described has a granulomatous necrotizing inflammation, which is highly suggestive of tuberculosis, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is prevalent. Tuberculosis often leads to the formation of caseating granulomas, which can undergo dystrophic calcification.

 

Dystrophic calcification occurs in areas of tissue damage or necrosis, such as caseating granulomas in tuberculosis. This type of calcification is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in dead or degenerating tissues, and importantly, it occurs despite normal serum calcium levels.

 

In contrast, metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues and is associated with hypercalcemia, which is not the case here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels: Metastatic calcification is not associated with normal calcium levels. It is typically associated with elevated serum calcium levels.

 

Option B. Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels: While metastatic calcification does occur with increased serum calcium levels, it is not related to granulomatous necrotizing inflammation like that seen in tuberculosis. This is seen in Sarcoidosis, parathyroid adenoma, chronic kidney disease, William syndrome.

 

Option D. Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels: Dystrophic calcification occurs in the context of normal serum calcium levels, not increased levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dystrophic calcification is a common finding in tissues undergoing necrosis, such as in caseating granulomas in tuberculosis, and it occurs with normal serum calcium levels.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought to the clinic for a routine developmental checkup. Upon examination, the child is able to sit unsupported and transfer toys from one hand to another. What is the earliest age at which this child could have first demonstrated the ability to transfer objects between hands? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 months


Transferring objects from one hand to another is a developmental milestone typically observed at around 6 months of age. At this age, children also begin to exhibit other fine motor skills such as unidextrous reach, where they reach for objects with one hand and can switch them between hands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 months: At 4 months, a child exhibits bidextrous reach, meaning they use both hands to reach for objects but are not yet able to transfer objects from hand to hand.

 

Option C. 9 months: By 9 months, the child demonstrates an immature pincer grasp, but transferring objects is usually established earlier by 6 months.

 

Option D. 12 months: At 12 months, the child typically develops a mature pincer grasp, allowing them to pick up small objects like beads using the thumb and forefinger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferring objects from one hand to another is a milestone typically achieved by 6 months of age. This is part of the fine motor skills development that also includes unidextrous reaching.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is used for Appendicectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grid iron incision

 

The grid iron incision, also known as the McArthur incision, is the preferred surgical approach for an appendectomy. This incision is made at the McBurney point, which is located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. The incision is muscle-splitting rather than cutting, which helps in minimizing muscle damage and promotes quicker recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kocher's incision: This is used for open cholecystectomy. It is a right subcostal incision, typically employed for gallbladder surgeries.

 

Option B. Morris incision: This is a flank incision used for accessing the retroperitoneal space, typically for renal surgeries.

 

Option D. Pfannensteil incision: This is a lower abdominal, transverse suprapubic incision often used for gynecological surgeries, such as cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grid iron (McArthur) incision is the standard incision used for appendectomy, made at the McBurney point and characterized by a muscle-splitting approach.

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5

 

To find the relative risk (RR) in this study, we first need to calculate the incidence of the disease in both the vaccinated (exposed) and non-vaccinated (non-exposed) groups.

 

Step 1: Incidence in the vaccinated group (exposed):

 

  • Number of vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 6
  • Incidence in the vaccinated group = 6/100 = 0.06

 

Step 2: Incidence in the non-vaccinated group (non-exposed):

 

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 12
  • Incidence in the non-vaccinated group = 12/100 = 0.12

 

Step 3: Calculate Relative Risk (RR):
 

  • RR = Incidence in the exposed group / Incidence in the non-exposed group
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

 

The relative risk of 0.5 indicates that the vaccinated individuals were half as likely to develop malaria compared to those who were not vaccinated. This suggests a protective effect of the vaccine against malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.

 

A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ERCP and Bile duct

 

The abdominal X-ray KUB image shows a stent, specifically a double J (DJ) stent, commonly used in surgeries. The appearance and orientation of the stent are key to identifying its location. In this case, the stent is positioned vertically, which indicates it is in the bile duct. The bile duct runs vertically in the body, and a biliary stent used in procedures like ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) would also be oriented vertically. Conversely, a stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally due to the anatomical layout of the pancreatic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP and Pancreatic duct: A stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally, not vertically, due to the horizontal course of the pancreatic duct. The given image shows a vertically oriented stent, which rules out this option.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic balloon catheter: This type of catheter would have a different appearance and is not typically placed in a vertical orientation like the stent shown in the X-ray.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous catheter: This type of catheter is used for different purposes and would not appear as a vertical stent in the abdominal X-ray. It also wouldn't be located in the bile duct or pancreatic duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vertical orientation of a stent on an abdominal X-ray is indicative of its placement in the bile duct, particularly in procedures involving ERCP.

questions.text: Following an accident, a patient presented with an inability to flex the MCP joint and extend the IP joint of his hand. Which nerve is damaged here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

The patient’s symptoms of being unable to flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints suggest a problem with the lumbrical muscles. The lumbricals are responsible for these movements. Specifically, the third and fourth lumbrical muscles, which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the ring and little fingers, are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Damage to the ulnar nerve can result in a condition known as "claw hand," where these functions are compromised, leading to the inability to perform the described movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily controls the extension of the wrist and fingers, but not the flexion of the MCP joints or extension of the IP joints. Hence, it is not involved in this condition.

 

Option B. Anterior interosseous nerve: This is a branch of the median nerve, primarily responsible for the motor function of some of the deep muscles in the forearm but does not innervate the lumbricals. Therefore, it is not responsible for the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm, responsible for elbow flexion, but it does not play a role in the movement of the fingers or hand. Therefore, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the third and fourth lumbricals, which are essential for flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. Damage to this nerve can lead to the characteristic "claw hand" deformity.

questions.text: The recommended free/residual chlorine level in the water after chlorination of a well is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5 ppm after 1 hour

 

The primary purpose of chlorination is to disinfect water and ensure that it is safe for consumption. After chlorination, it is important to have a certain level of free or residual chlorine in the water to maintain its safety as it passes through the distribution system. The residual chlorine provides ongoing disinfection to prevent contamination after the initial chlorination.

 

For well water, the recommended free or residual chlorine level should be 0.5 ppm (parts per million) after a contact period of 1 hour. This level is sufficient to kill most pathogens in the water and ensure it remains safe for consumption.

 

Maintaining this chlorine level is crucial as it indicates that the water has been effectively disinfected and is less likely to harbor harmful microorganisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Minimum Chlorine Levels:
    • Drinking Water: The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm).
    • Swimming Pools: A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness.
    • Killing Cyclopes: To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • Chloroscope device is used to measure chlorine levels in water, ensuring to meet the health and safety standards.
  • Orthotolidine Test is utilized for measuring the chlorine content in water, confirming whether the necessary disinfection levels are being maintained.
  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water, which helps determine how much bleaching powder should be added to achieve effective disinfection.
  • The main disinfecting agent in chlorine treatments is hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is effective in neutralizing pathogens and ensuring water safety.

questions.text: What is the typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 125 ml/min

 

The Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is a measure of how much blood is filtered by the glomeruli in the kidneys per minute. It is a critical indicator of kidney function. In a healthy adult, the typical GFR is approximately 125 ml/min. This value can vary based on factors such as age, sex, and body size, but 125 ml/min is generally accepted as the normal average for a healthy adult

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult is approximately 125 ml/min, reflecting normal kidney function.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

questions.text: A woman purchased a food item from a shopkeeper who was subsequently arrested for food adulteration. Meanwhile, the woman develops visual disturbances and cardiac failure. The underlying toxin is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sanguinarine

 

The question describes a case of food adulteration that led to symptoms such as visual disturbances (Glaucoma) and cardiac failure. These symptoms are characteristic of a condition known as epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of adulterated mustard oil. The toxic adulterant in this case is Argemone mexicana oil, which contains the toxin sanguinarine. Sanguinarine inhibits the oxidation of pyruvic acid in the blood, leading to the symptoms observed in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BOAA: This is a toxin found in Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal) and can lead to neurolathyrism, a condition characterized by neuromuscular symptoms, not by visual disturbances or cardiac failure.

 

Option C. Ergot toxin: This toxin is associated with ergotism, which causes symptoms like hallucinations, gangrene, and convulsions.

 

Option D. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxin is a mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus species, often found in improperly stored food items like grains and nuts. It is a potent carcinogen but does not cause the acute symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration diseases:

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The patient's symptoms of painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) are characteristic of Chancroid. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender, often pus-filled lymph nodes (buboes) in the groin.

 

When differentiating between sexually transmitted infections that cause genital ulcers, it is important to note whether the ulcers are painful or painless:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum): Incorrect because the genital ulcers in LGV are typically painless and transient. Although buboes are seen in LGV, the painful ulcers in this case suggest another diagnosis.

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: Incorrect because, although Herpes genitalis presents with painful ulcers, it usually does not involve painful inguinal buboes. Additionally, a history of recurrence might be mentioned, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Chancre (Syphilis): Incorrect because the ulcer in syphilis (chancre) is typically painless, and the lymphadenopathy is also painless.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

choices.text: Cherry red hypostasis due to CO

questions.text: A family died in a closed room which was full of smoke from woodfire. Which of the following is the finding seen on the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cherry red hypostasis due to CO

 

When a fire occurs in a closed space (home), the combustion is incomplete due to limited oxygen. This leads to the production of carbon monoxide (CO). Carbon monoxide binds with hemoglobin in the blood to form carboxyhemoglobin, which imparts a characteristic cherry red color to the hypostasis seen in the body post-mortem. This is a hallmark finding in CO poisoning and is used as a key diagnostic indicator.

 

Additionally, fires in industrial buildings (closed spaces) can produce cyanide due to the combustion of synthetic fibers containing nitrogen. However, for examination purposes, the cherry red color is most commonly associated with carbon monoxide poisoning.

 

Note - Fire in open space – the combustion is complete due to presence of sufficient oxygen, leads to production of CO2.

 

Postmortem staining –

 

Cherry red – CO poisoning, Cyanide poisoning, Cold (hypothermia)

 

Other Options:
